0. What is discrete mathematics?

0.1 It’s math you do quietly, right?

The phrase “discrete mathematics” is often used nebulously to refer to a certain branch of mathematics that, from the college point of view, is “not calculus” or perhaps is applicable to computer science. In this section, we will try to understand what it means for a topic to fall under the umbrella of discrete mathematics.

0.2 A tale of two sets

Throughout high school and college mathematics so far, you have largely been working with R\mathbf{R}R, the set of real numbers. This set includes virtually every number you can imagine, including 000, −1-1−1, 3/43/43/4, 0.60.60.6, 2\sqrt{2}2​, and π\piπ. (If you know what a complex number is, R\mathbf{R}R does not include those.)

One of the distinguishing features of R\mathbf{R}R is their density. Here’s the idea. If I give you any two real numbers – say, 000 and 111 – you can find one in between – say, 1/π1/\pi1/π. Then between 000 and 1/π1/\pi1/π you can find another. And so on.

Another set with which you are familiar is N\mathbf{N}N, the set of natural numbers. The natural numbers are the counting numbers starting with 000 (in this book, anyway). If I give you two natural numbers like 000 and 111, you cannot find another natural in between. In this sense, the natural numbers are – you guessed it! – discrete. We often call N\mathbf{N}N countable and R\mathbf{R}R uncountable, because the elements of the latter cannot be listed. (You will never get to 1.)

So, discrete mathematics is the study of objects that are countable.

0.3 Some examples

Here are some questions we might try to answer using discrete mathematics. In fact, you will be able to answer all these questions by the end of the book.

Suppose we have a program that will activate condition 4 if conditions 1 and 2 are met but not condition 3. How do we know when condition 4 is active?

We can use logic to represent this program with the statement (p∧q∧¬r)→s(p \wedge q \wedge \neg r) \to s(p∧q∧¬r)→s, and then use truth tables to determine exactly when condition 4 will trigger.

Which of these two programs is more efficient?

A sequence is a function of natural numbers. An example is the number (an)(a_n)(an​) of steps it takes to run a computer program with nnn inputs. If (an)(a_n)(an​) grows must faster than (bn)(b_n)(bn​) does, that can tell us that one program scales worse for large quantities of data.

Some members of a community are sick. How do we know who is at risk of being infected?

Relations encode relationships between sets of objects. We may compose relations to iterate those relationships over and over again. If person xxx is sick and has come into contact with person yyy, and yyy has come into contact with person zzz, and zzz has since seen www, then www is at risk.

0.4 How to use this book

Chapters 1-4, 6, and 8 must be done in order. Chapters 5 and chapter 7 can be skipped for a non-computer science audience, so long as the student learns what a bit string is in time for chapter 9.

Then, chapters 9-13 (on combinatorics) and chapters 14-18 (on relations) may be attempted in that order, or in the order 14-18; 9-13. Be aware that some of the exercises in 14-18 assume that the reader has learned the combinatorial material. So, if you follow the alternate order, leave these exercises for later. Chapter 17 involves a detour into modular arithmetic that can be skipped if desired.

This book is paired with a four playlists on my YouTube channel. Playlist 1 (sets and logic) maps to chapters 1-3, playlist 2 (proof and recursion) maps to chapters 4-8, playlist 3 (combinatorics) maps to chapters 9-13, and playlist 4 (relations) maps to chapters 14-18.

These videos are very short demonstrations and examples of the material pursued in depth by the book. I am not sure which ordering is better: book then videos, or videos then book. Choose your own adventure.

Each chapter has a section of exercises located at – . These exercises should be attempted after each chapter. If you are in MATH 174 at Coastal Carolina University, these exercises are your homework.

I try to use the invitational “we” throughout the book and maintain a playful formality, but sometimes my annoying authorial voice pokes through. I try to tag these like so: (DW: I like parentheticals.)

Each chapter ends with several “takeaways” that summarize the chapter. Starting with the fourth chapter, if necessary, each chapter begins with hint to go back and look at some things you may not have thought about in a while.

0.5 The point of this book

– is to teach you discrete mathematics, of course.

But much more broadly, this book is intended to teach you to think mathematically. You may be a student who has never seen any math beyond calculus or algebra, or perhaps you dread doing math. The point of this book is to get you to learn to think deeply, communicate carefully, and not shy away from difficult material.

As you proceed, have something to write with on hand. Work each example along with the book. Then, at the end of each chapter, work the exercises. Some (denoted with a ∗*∗) are more difficult than others, but are well worth doing to improve your understanding. Work along with someone at roughly your skill level, share solutions and ask each other questions.

Everyone can be a “math person!” So, let’s get started.

1. Sets

Videos:

  • Introduction to sets
  • Containment
  • Algebra of sets

1.1 Membership

For nearly all interested parties, sets form the foundation of all mathematics. Every mathematical objects you have ever encountered can be described as a set, from numbers themselves to functions and matrices.

We will say that a set is an unordered collection of objects, called its elements. When xxx is an element of the set XXX, we write x∈Xx \in Xx∈X.

Examples. Our starting point will be the set of all natural numbers,

N={0,1,2,3,…}. \mathbf{N} = \{0,1,2,3,\ldots \}.N={0,1,2,3,…}.

Certain sets are special enough to get their own names, with bold or “blackboard bold” face. Sometimes (especially in ink) you will see N\mathbb{N}N instead. Note that the elements of the set are enclosed in curly braces. Proper notation is not optional; using the wrong notation is like saying “milk went store” to mean “I went to the store to get milk.” Finally, not everyone agrees that 000 is a natural number, but computer scientists do.

If we take N\mathbf{N}N and include its negatives, we get the integers

Z={…,−2,−1,0,1,2,…}. \mathbf{Z} = \{\ldots, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, \ldots \}.Z={…,−2,−1,0,1,2,…}.

Notice that in the case of an infinite set, or even a large finite set, we can use ellipses when a pattern is established. One infinite set that defies a pattern is the set of prime numbers. You may recall that a prime number is a positive integer ppp with exactly two factors: itself and 111. We may list a few: 2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19,23,2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23,2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19,23, but there is no pattern that allows us to employ ellipses.

Fortunately there is another way to write down a set. All previous examples have used roster notation, where the elements are simply listed. It may be more convenient to use set-builder notation, where the set is instead described with a rule that exactly characterizes this element. In that case, the set of primes can be written as

{ p ∣  p is a prime number}. \{ \, p \, | \; p \text{ is a prime number} \}.{p∣p is a prime number}.

To provide one last example, consider the set of all U.S. states. In roster notation this set is a nightmare: {AL, AK, AZ, AR, CA, CO, CT, DE, FL, GA, HI, ID, IL, IN, IA, KS, KY, LA, ME, MD, MA, MI, MN, MS, MO, MT, NE, NV, NH, NJ, NM, NY, NC, ND, OH, OK, OR, PA, RI, SC, SD, TN, TX, UT, VT, VA, WA, WV, WI, WY}. But in set-builder notation we simply write

{ S ∣ S is a U.S. state}. \{ \, S \, | \, S \text{ is a U.S. state} \}.{S∣S is a U.S. state}.

Definition 1.1.1. Two sets XXX and YYY are equal if they contain exactly the same elements, in which case we write X=YX=YX=Y.

Remember that sets are unordered, so even {a,b}={b,a}\{a,b\}=\{b,a\}{a,b}={b,a}.

Definition 1.1.2. Let XXX be a finite set. Its cardinality, denoted ∣X∣|X|∣X∣, is the number of elements in XXX.

Example. If X={a,b,c}X=\{a,b,c\}X={a,b,c}, then ∣X∣=3|X|=3∣X∣=3.

We can talk about the cardinality of infinite sets, but that is far beyond the scope of this course.

1.2 Containment

One of the most important ideas when dealing with sets is that of a subset.

Definition 1.2.1. Let XXX and YYY be sets. We say XXX is a subset of YYY if every element of XXX is also an element of YYY.

Examples. Put X={a,b,c}X = \{a,b,c\}X={a,b,c}, Y={a,c}Y = \{a,c\}Y={a,c}, and Z={b}Z=\{b\}Z={b}. Then Y⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X, Z⊆XZ \subseteq XZ⊆X, but Y⊈ZY \not\subseteq ZY​⊆Z and Z⊈YZ \not\subseteq YZ​⊆Y.

In mathematics, true statements are either definitions (those taken for granted) or theorems (those proven from the definitions). We will learn to prove more difficult theorems later, but for now we can prove a simple one.

Theorem 1.2.2. Every set is a subset of itself.

A proof is simply an argument that convinces its reader of the truth of a mathematical fact. Valid proofs must only use definitions and the hypotheses of the theorem; it is not correct to assume more than you are given. So the ingredients in the proof of this theorem are simply going to be a set and the definition of the word “subset.”

Proof. Let XXX be a set. Suppose xxx is an arbitrary element of XXX. Then, xxx is also an element of XXX. Because XXX was shown to have any arbitrary element of XXX, then X⊆XX \subseteq XX⊆X. □\square□

Notice that the actual make-up of the set XXX is irrelevant. If XXX has an element, then XXX also has that element, and that is all it takes to conclude X⊆XX \subseteq XX⊆X. It would be incorrect to try to prove X⊆XX \subseteq XX⊆X from an example: just because {0}\{0\}{0} is a subset of itself doesn’t necessarily mean that {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1} is!

We will discuss logic and proof-writing at length as we continue. For now, let’s continue learning about sets and proving the “simple” theorems as we go.

Definition 1.2.3. The set with no elements is called the empty set, denoted {}\{ \}{} or ∅\varnothing∅.

With a little logical sleight-of-hand, we can prove another (much more surprising) theorem.

Theorem 1.2.4. The empty set is a subset of every set.

Proof. Let XXX be a set. We may conclude ∅⊆X\varnothing \subseteq X∅⊆X if every element of ∅\varnothing∅ is an element of XXX. Observe that this statement is equivalent to saying that no elements of ∅\varnothing∅ are not elements of XXX. Because there are no elements of ∅\varnothing∅ at all, this statement is true; and we are done. □\square□

Perhaps you already agree with the central claim of the proof, that there are no difference between the statements "everything in ∅\varnothing∅ is in XXX" and "nothing in ∅\varnothing∅ is not in XXX". If you do not, take it on faith for now. When we study predicate logic later you will have the tools to convince yourself of the claim.

Such a statement that relies on the emptiness of ∅\varnothing∅ is said to be vacuously true.

When X⊆YX \subseteq YX⊆Y, we say YYY contains XXX or that YYY is a superset of XXX. With the idea of containment in hand we can construct a new type of set.

Definition 1.2.5. Let XXX be a set. Its power set is the set P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X) whose elements are the subsets of XXX. That is,
P(X)={ E ∣ E⊆X }. \mathcal{P}(X) = \{ \, E \, | \, E \subseteq X \, \}.P(X)={E∣E⊆X}.

Wait - our elements are sets? Yes, and this is perfectly fine! Elements can be all sorts of things, other sets included. When we have a “set of sets” we typically refer to it as a family or a collection to avoid using the same word and over and over.

Example. Let X={a,b,c}X = \{a,b,c\}X={a,b,c}. Then

P(X)={∅,{a},{b},{c},{a,b},{a,c},{b,c},X}. \mathcal{P}(X) = \{ \varnothing, \{a\}, \{b\}, \{c\}, \{a,b\}, \{a,c\}, \{b,c\}, X\}. P(X)={∅,{a},{b},{c},{a,b},{a,c},{b,c},X}.

Notice that the number of sets in P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X) can be derived from the number of elements in XXX.

Theorem 1.2.6. If XXX is finite, then ∣P(X)∣=2∣X∣|\mathcal{P}(X)|=2^{|X|}∣P(X)∣=2∣X∣.

We will come back to prove this theorem much later, once we have learned how to count!

1.3 The algebra of sets

You are used to word “algebra” as it refers to a class where you must solve some equations for xxx. If you think about those classes, they are really about understanding operations and functions of real numbers. Think about it: a successful algebra student will know how to manipulate sums, products, polynomials, roots, and exponential functions – ways of combining and mapping real numbers.

So, “algebra” in general refers to the ways objects may be combined and mapped. In this section, we will see many ways that sets can be combined to produce new sets.

Definition 1.3.1. Let XXX and YYY be sets. Their union is the set X∪YX \cup YX∪Y of all elements that are in at least one of XXX or YYY; in set builder notation this is
X∪Y={ x ∣ x∈X or x∈Y}. X \cup Y = \{\, x \, | \, x \in X \text{ or } x \in Y \}.X∪Y={x∣x∈X or x∈Y}.

Definition 1.3.2. Let XXX and YYY be sets. Their intersection is the set X∪YX \cup YX∪Y of all elements that are in both XXX and YYY; in set builder notation this is
X∩Y={ x ∣ x∈X and x∈Y}. X \cap Y = \{\, x \, | \, x \in X \text{ and } x \in Y \}.X∩Y={x∣x∈X and x∈Y}.

A useful way to visualize combinations of sets is with a Venn diagram. The Venn diagrams for union and intersection are shown below.



Figure. On the left, the union of two sets; on the right, the intersection.

Example. Let X={1,2,3,4}X = \{1,2,3,4\}X={1,2,3,4} and Y={2,4,7,9}Y=\{2,4,7,9\}Y={2,4,7,9}. Their union is
X∪Y={1,2,3,4,7,9} X \cup Y = \{1,2,3,4,7,9\}X∪Y={1,2,3,4,7,9} and their intersection is X∩Y={2,4}.X \cap Y = \{2,4\}.X∩Y={2,4}. Notice that we do not repeat elements in a set. An element is either in the set or it isn’t. (A generalization, the multiset, will be developed in Chapter 11.) Therefore, ∣X∪Y∣|X \cup Y|∣X∪Y∣ (recall, the number of elements in the union) won’t just be ∣X∣+∣Y∣|X|+|Y|∣X∣+∣Y∣.

Theorem 1.3.3. If XXX and YYY are finite sets, then ∣X∪Y∣=∣X∣+∣Y∣−∣X∩Y∣.|X \cup Y| = |X|+|Y|-|X\cap Y|.∣X∪Y∣=∣X∣+∣Y∣−∣X∩Y∣.

Proof. If an element is only in XXX, it will be counted by ∣X∣|X|∣X∣. If an element is only in YYY, it will be counted by ∣Y∣|Y|∣Y∣. Therefore any elements in X∩YX \cap YX∩Y will be counted twice. There are exactly ∣X∩Y∣|X \cap Y|∣X∩Y∣ of these elements, so subtracting that amount gives ∣X∪Y∣|X \cup Y|∣X∪Y∣. □\square□

Definition 1.3.4. Let XXX and YYY be sets. The difference X−YX-YX−Y is the set of all elements in XXX but not YYY; i.e. X−Y={ x ∣ x∈X and x∉Y}.X-Y=\{ \, x \, | \, x \in X \text{ and } x \not\in Y\}.X−Y={x∣x∈X and x​∈Y}.

Example. Like before, let X={1,2,3,4}X = \{1,2,3,4\}X={1,2,3,4} and Y={2,4,7,9}Y=\{2,4,7,9\}Y={2,4,7,9}. Then X−Y={1,3}X-Y=\{1,3\}X−Y={1,3}. Notice that Y−X={7,9}Y-X=\{7,9\}Y−X={7,9}; just like with numbers, taking a diference is not commutative. (That is, the order matters.)

Often when working with sets there is a universal or ambient set, sometimes denoted Ω\OmegaΩ, that all of our sets are assumed to be subsets of. This set is typically inferred from context.

  • In calculus, this set might be R\mathbf{R}R.
  • If my set is “students taking MATH 174,” my universal set might be the set of all students at Coastal Carolina.
  • In probability theory, the sets are events (e.g. “the roll is odd”) and Ω\OmegaΩ is the sample space (e.g. all possible rolls of the die).

Definition 1.3.5. Let XXX be a set contained in some universal set Ω\OmegaΩ. The complement of XXX (relative to Ω\OmegaΩ), denoted X‾\overline{X}X, is all the elements not in XXX. In other words, X‾=Ω−X\overline{X}=\Omega-XX=Ω−X.



Figure. On the left, the difference of two sets shaded in pink. On the right, the complement of a set shaded in blue.

Example. Suppose X={a,b,c}X=\{a,b,c\}X={a,b,c} is contained in the universal set Ω={a,b,c,d,e}\Omega=\{a,b,c,d,e\}Ω={a,b,c,d,e}. Then X‾={d,e}\overline{X}=\{d,e\}X={d,e}.

Definition 1.3.6. Let XXX and YYY be sets. Their Cartesian product (in this book, just “product”) is the set X×Y={(x,y) ∣ x∈X and y∈Y}.X\times Y = \{(x,y)\,|\, x \in X \text{ and } y \in Y\}.X×Y={(x,y)∣x∈X and y∈Y}. The elements of the product are called ordered pairs.

As the name implies, the ordering of the entries in an ordered pair matters. Therefore, we will adopt the convention that unordered structures are enclosed in {\{{ curly braces }\}} and ordered structures are enclosed in ((( parentheses ))). The immediate consequence to this observation is that X×YX \times YX×Y is different from Y×XY \times XY×X.



Figure. A visualization of the product of two sets.

Examples. You are likely familiar with R2=R×R\mathbf{R}^2=\mathbf{R}\times\mathbf{R}R2=R×R, the Cartesian plane from algebra and calculus. The elements of this (infinite) set are ordered pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) where both xxx and yyy are real numbers.

To make a discrete example, put X={a,b,c}X=\{a,b,c\}X={a,b,c} and Y={1,2}Y=\{1,2\}Y={1,2}. Then
X×Y={(a,1),(a,2),(b,1),(b,2),(c,1),(c,2)}. X \times Y = \{(a, 1), (a,2), (b,1), (b,2), (c,1), (c,2)\}.X×Y={(a,1),(a,2),(b,1),(b,2),(c,1),(c,2)}. As an exercise, calculate Y×XY \times XY×X yourself. The pair (1,a)(1,a)(1,a) is an element.

Theorem 1.3.7. If XXX and YYY are finite sets, then ∣X×Y∣=∣X∣∣Y∣|X \times Y| = |X||Y|∣X×Y∣=∣X∣∣Y∣.

Proof. The elements of X×YX\times YX×Y may be tabulated into a rectangle, where each row corresponds to an element of XXX and each column corresponds to an element of YYY. There are ∣X∣|X|∣X∣ rows and ∣Y∣|Y|∣Y∣ columns and therefore ∣X∣∣Y∣|X||Y|∣X∣∣Y∣ elements in the table. □\square□

1.4 Operations involving more than two sets

Note: While this section is cool, we will not make use of its content very often in this course. You may choose to skip this section for now and return to it after Chapter 8, when you are more comfortable with the material.

There is one last thing to say about sets (for now, anyway). There is no reason to limit ourselves to two sets in union, intersection, and product. If we have a family of nnn sets X1,X2,…,XnX_1, X_2, \ldots, X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​, we may take nnn-ary unions, intersections, and products.

The nnn-ary union ⋃i=1nXi=X1∪X2∪⋯∪Xn\bigcup_{i=1}^n X_i = X_1 \cup X_2 \cup \cdots \cup X_ni=1⋃n​Xi​=X1​∪X2​∪⋯∪Xn​ is the set of elements that are in at least one of the sets XiX_iXi​.

The nnn-ary intersection ⋂i=1nXi=X1∩X2∩⋯∩Xn\bigcap_{i=1}^n X_i = X_1 \cap X_2 \cap \cdots \cap X_ni=1⋂n​Xi​=X1​∩X2​∩⋯∩Xn​ is the set of elements that are in all of the sets XiX_iXi​.

The nnn-ary product ∏i=1nXi=X1×X2×⋯×Xn\prod_{i=1}^n X_i = X_1 \times X_2 \times \cdots \times X_ni=1∏n​Xi​=X1​×X2​×⋯×Xn​ is the set of ordered nnn-tuples (x1,x2,…,xn)(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n)(x1​,x2​,…,xn​), where the element xix_ixi​ is a member of the set XiX_iXi​.

Suppose instead the family X1,X2,…X_1, X_2, \ldotsX1​,X2​,… is infinite. We will, exactly once in this book, need to take an infinite union. The infinite union ⋃i=1∞Xi=X1∪X2∪⋯\bigcup_{i=1}^\infty X_i = X_1 \cup X_2 \cup \cdots i=1⋃∞​Xi​=X1​∪X2​∪⋯ is the set of all elements that are in at least one of the XiX_iXi​. (Notice that the definition hasn’t changed – just the number of sets!) Likewise the infinite intersection ⋂i=1nXi=X1∩X2∩⋯\bigcap_{i=1}^n X_i = X_1 \cap X_2 \cap \cdots i=1⋂n​Xi​=X1​∩X2​∩⋯ is the set of elements in all the XiX_iXi​.

Takeaways

  • A set is a collection of objects. Given a mathematical object, there is almost definitely a way to define that object as a set.
  • A given set has many subsets, the collection of which forms its power set.
  • The cardinality of a finite set is the number of its elements.
  • There are many ways to combine and manipulate sets: union, intersection, difference, and product.

Chapter 1 problems

2. Propositional logic

Videos:

  • Negation, conjunction, and disjunction
  • Conditional statements
  • Compound statements
  • Rules of inference
  • Logical equivalence

In mathematics, we spend a lot of time worried about whether a sentence is true or false. This is fine in the case of a simple sentence such as “The number 222 is prime.” (That sentence is true.) But there are much more complicated sentences lurking around, and whole constellations of sentences whose truth depends on one another. (An unsolved problem in mathematics is deciding whether the Riemann hypothesis, a statement about the prime numbers, is true. Most people believe it is, and many results in the literature are true given the hypothesis. The Riemann hypothesis is going to make or break a lot of research.)

So, we are interested in tools that will allow us to judge whether complicated statements are true. Such models of truth are called logic.

2.1 Statements and connectives

Definition 2.1.1. A statement is a sentence that is either true or false.

Examples. “The number 222 is prime” and “It is perfectly legal to jaywalk” are statements. Non-statements include questions (“Is it raining?”), commands (“Do your homework”), and opinions (“Mint chocolate chip ice cream is the superior flavor”). It is important to note, not necessarily for mathematical purposes, that opinions are statements of pure taste. Claims whose truth values exist but are unknown are beliefs.

Atomic propositional statements of the type discussed in this chapter are flatly always true or false. You may think of them in the same way you think of constant functions in algebra. They are denoted with lowercase letters ppp, qqq, rrr, etc. If the only statements were atomic, logic would be boring. Fortunately, we can combine statements with connectives. In the next chapter, we will look at predicate statements whose truth values depend on an input. Likewise, these may be thought of as the non-constant functions.

Compound statements arise from combining atomic statements with connectives. They are denoted using Greek letters like φ\varphiφ (“phi”), ψ\psiψ (“psi”), and γ\gammaγ (“gamma”). The truth of a compound statement depends on the connectives involved and the truth values of the constituent statements. A tool for determining the truth of a compound statement is called a truth table.

In a truth table for the compound statement φ\varphiφ, the left side of the table is the atomic statements involved in φ\varphiφ and the right side of the table is φ\varphiφ itself. Each row gives a possible combination of truth values for the atomic statements, and the corresponding truth value for φ\varphiφ. At this point, it is easier to start introducing connectives and seeing some truth tables.

Definition 2.1.2. Let ppp be a statement. Its negation is the statement ¬p\neg p¬p, the statement that is true exactly when ppp is false and vice-versa.

The statement ¬p\neg p¬p is typically read "not ppp" or “it is not the case that ppp is true.” If we have an English rendering of ppp, we try to write ¬p\neg p¬p in a natural-sounding way that also conveys its logical structure.

Example. Suppose ppp represents the statement “It is raining.” Then, ¬p\neg p¬p stands for “It is not raining.”

Below is the truth table for ¬p\neg p¬p.

ppp ¬p\neg p¬p
TTT FFF
FFF TTT

As you can see, on the left are columns corresponding to the atomic statements involved in ¬p\neg p¬p (just ppp), and each row is a possible combination of truth values for these statements. Here is a quick, useful theorem without proof:

Theorem 2.1.3. If the compound statement φ\varphiφ involves nnn different atomic statements, then its truth table has 2n2^n2n rows.

Look familiar? We will prove this theorem when we prove the related theorem about power sets later on.

Negation is called a unary connective because it only involves one statement. Our remaining connectives are all binary connectives, as they combine two statements.

Definition 2.1.4. Let ppp and qqq be statements. Their conjunction is the statement p∧qp \wedge qp∧q, which is true only when ppp and qqq are both true.

The symbol in the conjunction is called a “wedge,” and p∧qp \wedge qp∧q is read "ppp and qqq." This definition is meant to be analogous to our English understanding of the word “and.” The statements ppp and qqq are called conjuncts.

Example. Letting ppp be “It is raining” and qqq be “I brought an umbrella,” the statement p∧qp \wedge qp∧q is “It is raining and I brought an umbrella.” The statement is true only if it is currently raining and the speaker brought an umbrella. If it is not raining, or if the speaker did not bring their umbrella, the conjunction is false.

Here is the truth table for p∧qp \wedge qp∧q:

ppp qqq p∧qp \wedge qp∧q
TTT TTT TTT
TTT FFF FFF
FFF TTT FFF
FFF FFF FFF

Notice that this table is organized intentionally, not haphazardly. The rows are divided into halves, where ppp is true in one half and then false in the other half. The rows where ppp is true are further subdivided into half where qqq is true and half where qqq is false. If there were a third letter, we would subdivide the rows again, and so on. This method of organizing the truth table allows us to ensure we did not forget a row. Our leftmost atomic letter column will always be half true followed by half false, and the rightmost atomic letter column will always alternate between true and false.

Definition 2.1.5. Let ppp and qqq be statements. Their disjunction is the statement p∨qp \vee qp∨q, which is true if at least one of ppp or qqq is true.

The symbol in the conjunction is called a “vee” and p∨qp \vee qp∨q is read "ppp or qqq." This definition is meant to be analogous to our English understanding of the word “or.” The statements ppp and qqq are called disjuncts. (Did you notice that I was able to copy and paste from an above paragraph? Conjunction and disjunction share a very similar structure.)

Example. Letting ppp be “It is raining” and qqq be “I brought an umbrella,” the statement p∨qp \vee qp∨q is “It is raining or I brought an umbrella.” This time, the speaker only needs to meet one of their conditions. They are telling the truth as long as it is raining or they brought an umbrella, or even if both statements are true.

The truth table for p∨qp \vee qp∨q follows.

ppp qqq p∨qp \vee qp∨q
TTT TTT TTT
TTT FFF TTT
FFF TTT TTT
FFF FFF FFF

Of great importance to computer science and electrical engineering, but not so much in mathematics (so it will not appear again in this book), is the exclusive disjunction (or “exclusive-or”). It is a modified disjunction where exactly one of the disjuncts must be true.

Definition 2.1.6. If ppp and qqq are statements, their exclusive disjunction is the statement p⊕qp \oplus qp⊕q, which is true if and only if exactly one of ppp and qqq is true.

The statement p⊕qp \oplus qp⊕q is read "ppp exclusive-or qqq."

Example. The statement “You can have the soup or the salad” is likely meant as an exclusive disjunction.

In mathematics, disjunctions are generally considered inclusive unless stated otherwise. (An example for us all to follow!)

Our next connective is probably the most important, as it conveys the idea of one statement implying another. As we discussed earlier in the chapter, mathematics is nothing but such statements. It is also the only connective that is not relatively easy to understand given its English interpretation. So we will begin with the truth table, and think carefully about each row.

Definition 2.1.7. If ppp and qqq are statements, the conditional statement p→qp \to qp→q is true if ppp can never be true while qqq is false.

There are many ways to read p→qp \to qp→q, including “if ppp, then qqq,” "ppp implies qqq“, and "ppp is sufficient for qqq.” The statement before the arrow is the antecedent and the following statement is the consequent. Here is the conditional’s truth table.

ppp qqq p→qp \to qp→q
TTT TTT TTT
TTT FFF FFF
FFF TTT TTT
FFF FFF TTT

That p→qp \to qp→q is true in the bottom two rows may surprise you. So, let’s consider each row separately.

Example. Let ppp be “You clean your room” and qqq be “I will pay you $10,” so that p→qp\to qp→q is “If you clean your room, then I will pay you $10.”

In the case that both ppp and qqq are true, the speaker has told the truth. You cleaned, and you were paid. All is well.

In the case that ppp is true but qqq is false, the speaker has lied. You cleaned the room, but you did not earn your money.

What if ppp is false? Well, then the speaker did not lie. The speaker said that if you clean your room you will be paid. If the room isn’t cleaned, then p→qp \to qp→q cannot be falsified, no matter where qqq is true or false.

If that explanation is not sufficient for you, reread the definition of the conditional: p→qp \to qp→q being true means that ppp cannot be true without qqq. If you are unsatisfied by the English connection, then consider p→qp \to qp→q to be a purely formal object whose definition is the above truth table.

Definition 2.1.8. If ppp and qqq are statements, the biconditional statement p↔qp \leftrightarrow qp↔q is true if ppp and qqq are both true, or both false.

The statement p↔qp \leftrightarrow qp↔q may be read as "ppp if and only if qqq, "ppp is necessary and sufficient for qqq," or "ppp is equivalent to qqq." Here is the truth table.

ppp qqq p→qp \to qp→q
TTT TTT TTT
TTT FFF FFF
FFF TTT FFF
FFF FFF TTT

Example. Let ppp be “You clean your room” and qqq be “I will pay you $10,” so that p↔qp\leftrightarrow qp↔q is “I will give you $10 if and only if you clean your room.” (The statements were reordered for readability. We will see later in the chapter that this is the same statement, but this wouldn’t work for p→qp \to qp→q.) This time, the clean room and the $10 paycheck are in total correspondence; one doesn’t happen without the other.

2.2 Connecting connectives

We are not required to use one connective at a time, of course. Most statements involve two or more connectives being combined at once. If φ\varphiφ and ψ\psiψ are statements, then so are: ¬φ\neg \varphi¬φ, φ∧ψ\varphi \wedge \psiφ∧ψ, φ∨ψ\varphi \vee \psiφ∨ψ, φ→ψ\varphi \to \psiφ→ψ, and φ↔ψ\varphi \leftrightarrow \psiφ↔ψ. This fact allows us to combine as many connectives and statements as we like.

How should we read the statement p∧q→rp \wedge q \to rp∧q→r? Should it be read "ppp; also, if qqq then rrr"? Or, “If ppp and qqq, then rrr?” Just like with arithmetic, there are conventions defining which connective to apply first: negation, then conjunction/disjunction, then implication, then bi-implication. So, "If ppp and qqq, then rrr" is correct. However, to eliminate confusion in this book we will always use parentheses to make our statements clear. Therefore, we would write this statement as (p∧q)→r(p \wedge q) \to r(p∧q)→r.

Remember that a statement involving nnn letters will have 2n2^n2n rows in its truth table. The column for the left-most statement letter should be true for half the rows then false for half the rows, and you should continue dividing the rows in half so that the right-most statement letter’s column is alternating between true and false.

Finally, it is a good idea to break a statement into small “chunks” and make a column for each “chunk” separately. Observe the following example.

Example. Write down the truth table for the statement (p∧q)→(r→¬s)(p \wedge q) \to (r \to \neg s)(p∧q)→(r→¬s). When is this statement false?

Since the statement has 444 letters, there will be 24=162^4=1624=16 rows to the truth table. Let’s go through the first row very slowly, where all four atomic statements are true. Then p∧qp \wedge qp∧q is true and ¬s\neg s¬s is false. Since rrr is true and ¬s\neg s¬s is false, that means r→¬sr \to \neg sr→¬s is false. Finally, because its antecedent is true and its consequent is false, the compound statement (p∧q)→(r→¬s)(p \wedge q) \to (r \to \neg s)(p∧q)→(r→¬s) would be false.

Here is the full truth table. Be sure you understand how each row is calculated.

ppp qqq rrr sss p∧qp \wedge qp∧q ¬s\neg s¬s r→¬sr \to \neg sr→¬s (p∧q)→(r→¬s)(p \wedge q) \to (r \to \neg s)(p∧q)→(r→¬s)
TTT TTT TTT TTT TTT FFF FFF FFF
TTT TTT TTT FFF TTT TTT TTT TTT
TTT TTT FFF TTT TTT FFF TTT TTT
TTT TTT FFF FFF TTT TTT TTT TTT
TTT FFF TTT TTT FFF FFF FFF TTT
TTT FFF TTT FFF FFF TTT TTT TTT
TTT FFF FFF TTT FFF FFF TTT TTT
TTT FFF FFF FFF FFF TTT TTT TTT
FFF TTT TTT TTT FFF FFF FFF TTT
FFF TTT TTT FFF FFF TTT TTT TTT
FFF TTT FFF TTT FFF FFF TTT TTT
FFF TTT FFF FFF FFF TTT TTT TTT
FFF FFF TTT TTT FFF FFF FFF TTT
FFF FFF TTT FFF FFF TTT TTT TTT
FFF FFF FFF TTT FFF FFF TTT TTT
FFF FFF FFF FFF FFF TTT TTT TTT

There are tricks to calculate truth tables more efficiently. However, it wouldn’t do you any good to read them; they must come with practice.

2.3 Inference and equivalence

Mathematics is all about relationships. If the statement φ→ψ\varphi \to \psiφ→ψ is always true, then it tells us that whenever φ\varphiφ is true then ψ\psiψ must be as well. If the statement φ↔ψ\varphi \leftrightarrow \psiφ↔ψ is always true, then it tells us that from the point of view of logic φ\varphiφ and ψ\psiψ are actually the same statement. That is, it is never possible for them to have different truth values.

Definition 2.3.1. A tautology is a statement that is always true, denoted TTT.

Definition 2.3.2. A contradiction is a statement that is always false, denoted FFF.

Definition 2.3.3. A rule of inference is a tautological conditional statement. If φ→ψ\varphi \to \psiφ→ψ is a rule of inference, then we say φ\varphiφ implies ψ\psiψ and write φ⇒ψ\varphi \Rightarrow \psiφ⇒ψ.

Remember that a conditional statement does not say that its antecedent and consequent are both true. It says that if its antecedent is true, its consequent must also be true.

There are many rules of inference, but we will explore two.

Definition 2.3.4. Modus ponens is the statement that says we may infer qqq from p→qp \to qp→q and ppp. Symbolically: [(p→q)∧p]→q.[(p \to q) \wedge p] \to q.[(p→q)∧p]→q.
Example. Consider the conditional statement “If you clean your room, then I will give you $10.” If the speaker is trustworthy, and we clean our room, then we may conclude we will be receiving $10.

Another example: “If a function is differentiable, then it is continuous.” (You may know the meanings of these words, but it is not important.) If this statement is true, and the function fff is differentiable, then without any further work we know that fff is continuous.

Theorem 2.3.5. Modus ponens is a rule of inference.

Notice that in the definition no claim is made that modus ponens is always true. That is up to us.

Since we know how to use truth tables, we may construct one to show that [(p→q)∧p]→q[(p \to q) \wedge p] \to q[(p→q)∧p]→q is always true. Before reading the table below, try to make your own!

ppp qqq (p→q)(p \to q)(p→q) (p→q)∧p(p \to q) \wedge p(p→q)∧p [(p→q)∧p]→q[(p \to q) \wedge p] \to q[(p→q)∧p]→q
TTT TTT TTT TTT TTT
TTT FFF FFF FFF TTT
FFF TTT TTT FFF TTT
FFF FFF TTT FFF TTT

Proof. The above table shows that [(p→q)∧p]→q[(p \to q) \wedge p] \to q[(p→q)∧p]→q is true no matter the truth of ppp and qqq. □\square□

Definition 2.3.6. In the context of conditional statements, transitivity is the rule that if ppp implies qqq and qqq implies rrr, then ppp implies rrr. Or, [(p→q)∧(q→r)]→(p→r).[(p \to q) \wedge (q \to r)] \to (p \to r).[(p→q)∧(q→r)]→(p→r).

The wording of the definition above should you make you suspicious that this is not the only time we will see transitivity. In fact, you may have seen it before…

Example. If you give a mouse a cookie, then he will ask for a glass of milk. If he asks for a glass of milk, then he will also ask for a straw. Therefore, if you give a mouse of cookie then he will ask for a straw.

Theorem 2.3.7. Transitivity is a rule of inference.

We could simply write down another truth table and call it a day. In fact, go ahead and make sure you can prove transitivity with a truth table. Once you’re done, we’ll try something slicker to prove transitivity.

Proof. Suppose that p→qp \to qp→q and q→rq \to rq→r are true statements, and that moreover ppp is true. By modus ponens, qqq must also be true. Then, rrr is true, by a second application of modus ponens. Therefore, if ppp is true, rrr must be also; this is the definition of p→rp \to rp→r. □\square□

Pretty cool, right? We can cite proven theorems to prove a new one.

Does it work the other way? In other words: if I know that [(p→q)∧(q→r)]⇒(p→r)[(p \to q) \wedge (q \to r)] \Rightarrow (p \to r)[(p→q)∧(q→r)]⇒(p→r), does that mean (p→r)⇒[(p→q)∧(q→r)](p \to r) \Rightarrow [(p \to q) \wedge (q \to r)](p→r)⇒[(p→q)∧(q→r)]? Regrettably, no: consider the case there ppp and rrr are true but qqq is false.

Some rules of inference do work both ways. These are called equivalences.

Definition 2.3.8. If φ↔ψ\varphi \leftrightarrow \psiφ↔ψ is a tautology, then it is an equivalence and φ\varphiφ and ψ\psiψ are equivalent statements. We write φ≡ψ\varphi \equiv \psiφ≡ψ.

Equivalent statements are not the same statements, but they are close enough from the point of view of logic. Equivalent statements are interchangeable, and may be freely substituted with one another.

We will quickly run through many equivalences before slowing down to prove a few.

Algebraic properties of conjunction, disjunction, and negation

Our first batch of statements should look familiar to you; these are the ways that statements “act like” numbers. As you read each one, try to justify to yourself why it might be true. If you aren’t sure of one, make a truth table.

Equivalence Name
p≡¬(¬p)p \equiv \neg (\neg p)p≡¬(¬p) Double negation
p∧q≡q∧pp \wedge q \equiv q \wedge pp∧q≡q∧p Commutative of conjunction
p∨q≡q∨pp \vee q \equiv q \vee pp∨q≡q∨p Commutative of disjunction
(p∧q)∧r≡p∧(q∧r)≡p∧q∧r(p \wedge q) \wedge r \equiv p \wedge (q \wedge r) \equiv p \wedge q \wedge r(p∧q)∧r≡p∧(q∧r)≡p∧q∧r Associativity of conjunction
(p∨q)∨r≡p∨(q∨r)≡p∨q∨r(p \vee q) \vee r \equiv p \vee (q \vee r) \equiv p \vee q \vee r(p∨q)∨r≡p∨(q∨r)≡p∨q∨r Associativity of disjunction
p∧T≡pp \wedge T \equiv pp∧T≡p Conjunctive identity
p∨F≡pp \vee F \equiv pp∨F≡p Disjunctive identity
p∧F≡Fp \wedge F \equiv Fp∧F≡F Conjunctive absorption
p∨T≡Tp \vee T \equiv Tp∨T≡T Disjunctive absorption
p∧¬p≡Fp \wedge \neg p \equiv Fp∧¬p≡F Conjunctive cancellation
p∨¬p≡Tp \vee \neg p \equiv Tp∨¬p≡T Disjunctive cancellation

Distributive properties

In our numbers, multiplication distributes over addition. This is one fact that is likely implemented twice in your head, once for a number: a(b+c)=ab+ac,a(b+c) = ab + ac,a(b+c)=ab+ac, and once for “the negative” (truly the number −1-1−1): −(b+c)=−b−c.-(b+c) = -b - c.−(b+c)=−b−c. However, these rules are one and the same; the distributive law. Likewise, we will have distributive laws for negation, conjunction, and disjunction.

Equivalence Name
¬(p∧q)≡¬p∨¬q\neg (p \wedge q) \equiv \neg p \vee \neg q¬(p∧q)≡¬p∨¬q DeMorgan’s law
¬(p∨q)≡¬p∧¬q\neg (p \vee q) \equiv \neg p \wedge \neg q¬(p∨q)≡¬p∧¬q DeMorgan’s law
p∧(q∨r)≡(p∨q)∧(p∨r)p \wedge (q \vee r) \equiv (p \vee q) \wedge (p \vee r)p∧(q∨r)≡(p∨q)∧(p∨r) Conjunction over disjunction
p∨(q∧r)≡(p∧q)∨(p∧r)p \vee (q \wedge r) \equiv (p \wedge q) \vee (p \wedge r)p∨(q∧r)≡(p∧q)∨(p∧r) Disjunction over conjunction

DeMorgan’s law is one of the most important facts in basic logic. In fact, we will see it three times before we are through. In English, DeMorgan’s law says that the negation of a conjunction is a disjunction and vice-versa.

To show that ¬(p∧q)\neg (p \wedge q)¬(p∧q) and ¬p∨¬q\neg p \vee \neg q¬p∨¬q are equivalent, we can show that the biconditional statement ¬(p∧q)↔¬p∨¬q\neg (p \wedge q) \leftrightarrow \neg p \vee \neg q¬(p∧q)↔¬p∨¬q is a tautology. Thinking about the definition of the biconditional gives us another way: we can show that the truth tables of ¬(p∧q)\neg (p \wedge q)¬(p∧q) and ¬p∨¬q\neg p \vee \neg q¬p∨¬q are the same; in other words, that both statements are always true and false for the same values of ppp and qqq.

Proof (of DeMorgan’s law for conjunction). Let ppp and qqq be statements. The statements ¬(p∧q)\neg (p \wedge q)¬(p∧q) and ¬p∨¬q\neg p \vee \neg q¬p∨¬q are equivalent, as shown by the below truth table.

ppp qqq ¬(p∧q)\neg (p \wedge q)¬(p∧q) ¬p∨¬q\neg p \vee \neg q¬p∨¬q
TTT TTT FFF FFF
TTT FFF TTT TTT
FFF TTT TTT TTT
FFF FFF TTT TTT

Therefore, ¬(p∧q)≡¬p∨¬q\neg (p \wedge q) \equiv \neg p \vee \neg q¬(p∧q)≡¬p∨¬q. □\square□

You’ll notice a few columns are skipped in the above truth table. After a few tables, it is more convenient to skip “easy” columns. For example, we know that p∧qp \wedge qp∧q is true only when ppp and qqq are both true, and false everywhere else. Therefore, we can “flip” that column to quickly get the column for ¬(p∧q)\neg (p \wedge q)¬(p∧q).

As an exercise, prove DeMorgan’s other law.

Properties of the conditional

Finally, we come to the properties of conditional (and biconditional) statements. These do not have “obvious” numerical counterparts, but are useful all the same.

Equivalence Name
p→q≡¬p∨qp \to q \equiv \neg p \vee qp→q≡¬p∨q Material implication
¬(p→q)≡p∧¬q\neg (p \to q) \equiv p \wedge \neg q¬(p→q)≡p∧¬q False conditional
p→q≡¬q→¬pp \to q \equiv \neg q \to \neg pp→q≡¬q→¬p Contraposition
p↔q≡(p→q)∧(q→p)p \leftrightarrow q \equiv (p \to q) \wedge (q \to p)p↔q≡(p→q)∧(q→p) Mutual implication

Material implication is the surprising result that the conditional is just a jumped-up disjunction! In fact, DeMorgan’s law, material implication, and mutual implication together prove that all of the connectives we’ve studied can be implemented with just two: negation and one other. However, this would make things difficult to read, so we allow the redundancy of five connectives.

Let’s prove material implication with a truth table, and then we will prove contraposition with another method.

Proof (of material implication). Let ppp and qqq be statements and observe that the truth tables for p→qp \to qp→q and ¬p∨q\neg p \vee q¬p∨q are the same:

ppp qqq p→qp \to qp→q ¬p∨q\neg p \vee q¬p∨q
TTT TTT TTT TTT
TTT FFF FFF FFF
FFF TTT TTT TTT
FFF FFF TTT TTT

Therefore, p→q≡¬p∨qp \to q \equiv \neg p \vee qp→q≡¬p∨q. □\square□

There is another way to think about material implication. The statement p→qp \to qp→q means that ppp never happens without qqq. Another way to say this is that qqq happens, or else ppp did not; so, ¬p∨q\neg p \vee q¬p∨q.

Before we prove contraposition by the other method, we must justify said method with a theorem.

Theorem 2.3.9. Statements φ\varphiφ and ψ\psiψ are equivalent if and only if φ⇒ψ\varphi \Rightarrow \psiφ⇒ψ and ψ⇒φ\psi \Rightarrow \varphiψ⇒φ are both rules of inference.

The phrase “if and only if” in a mathematical statement means that the statement “works both ways.” In this case, φ≡ψ\varphi \equiv \psiφ≡ψ means φ⇒ψ\varphi \Rightarrow \psiφ⇒ψ and ψ⇒φ\psi \Rightarrow \varphiψ⇒φ are both rules of inference; and conversely, φ⇒ψ\varphi \Rightarrow \psiφ⇒ψ and ψ⇒φ\psi \Rightarrow \varphiψ⇒φ both being rules of inference means φ≡ψ\varphi \equiv \psiφ≡ψ. It means that “φ≡ψ\varphi \equiv \psiφ≡ψ” and “”φ⇒ψ\varphi \Rightarrow \psiφ⇒ψ and ψ⇒φ\psi \Rightarrow \varphiψ⇒φ are both rules of inference" are equivalent statements. Fortunately, we already have a rule that justifies this equivalence.

Proof (of Theorem 2.3.9). Mutual implication says that p↔q≡(p→q)∧(q→p)p \leftrightarrow q \equiv (p \to q) \wedge (q \to p)p↔q≡(p→q)∧(q→p). □\square□

It’s that easy. Whenever we have a conditional statement and its converse (the order reversed), we have the biconditional; likewise, we may trade in a biconditional for two converse conditional statements.

Now we will prove contraposition by showing that p→qp\to qp→q implies ¬q→¬p\neg q \to \neg p¬q→¬p, and vice-versa. Before you read the below proof, write down these rules: material implication, double negation, and commutativity of disjunction.

Proof (of contraposition). Suppose ppp and qqq are statements and that p→qp \to qp→q is true. By material implication, ¬p∨q\neg p \vee q¬p∨q is true. Commutativity says this is the same as q∨¬pq \vee \neg pq∨¬p. So, we may apply material implication backwards, negating qqq this time, to get ¬q→¬p\neg q \to \neg p¬q→¬p; therefore, p→qp \to qp→q implies ¬q→¬p\neg q \to \neg p¬q→¬p.

Conversely, suppose ¬q→¬p\neg q \to \neg p¬q→¬p is true. Then material implication (and double negation) gives q∨¬pq \vee \neg pq∨¬p. We may commute the disjunction and apply material implication again, negating ¬p\neg p¬p, to get p→qp \to qp→q.

By mutual implication, p→q≡¬q→¬pp \to q \equiv \neg q \to \neg pp→q≡¬q→¬p. □\square□

Takeaways

  • Statements may be modified and combined in (mainly) five ways: negation, conjunction, disjunction, implication (the conditional), and bi-implication (the biconditional).
  • A truth table allows us to see when a compound statement will be true or false.
  • If one statement always implies another, that implication is a rule of inference.
  • If two statements are always true or always false together, they are equivalent.
  • Rules of inference and equivalences may be justified with truth tables or algebraically.

Chapter 2 problems

3. Predicate logic

Videos:

  • Predicates
  • Introduction to quantifiers
  • Quantifiers, continued
  • Inference and equivalence with quantifiers

3.1 Predicates

Basic propositional logic as you learned it in the preceding chapter is powerful enough to give us the tools we will need to prove many theorems. However, it is deficient in one key area. Consider the following example.

Example. If Hypatia is a woman and all women are mortal, then Hypatia is mortal.

We can all agree that this statement is a tautology; that is, if it is true that Hypatia is a woman (she was; she was a Greek mathematician contemporary with Diophantus) and if it is true that all women are mortal (as far as we know this is the case) then it must follow that Hypatia is mortal (she was murdered in 415).

So the statement is a tautology. If so, the truth table would confirm it. Let (p∧q)→r(p \wedge q) \to r(p∧q)→r symbolize the statement, where rrr stands for the statement that Hypatia is mortal.

ppp qqq rrr p∧qp\wedge qp∧q (p∧q)→r(p \wedge q)\to r(p∧q)→r
TTT TTT TTT TTT TTT
TTT TTT FFF TTT FFF
TTT FFF TTT FFF TTT
TTT FFF FFF FFF TTT
FFF TTT TTT FFF TTT
FFF TTT FFF FFF TTT
FFF FFF TTT FFF TTT
FFF FFF FFF FFF TTT

Oh no! Our second row gives that the statement is false when rrr is false but ppp and qqq are true. What gives?

Well, consider the statement “If pigs fly and the Pope turns into a bear, then Bob will earn an A on the exam.” Now it is not so clear that this is a tautology, because pigs, the Pope, and Bob’s grade presumably have nothing to do with one another.

But Hypatia and the mortality of women do. What we will need is the ability to signify that two statements are related, whether in subject (e.g. Hypatia) or predicate (e.g. mortality). This is where predicate logic comes in to help.

Definition 3.1.1. A predicate is a function P:Ω→{T,F}P:\Omega \to \{T,F\}P:Ω→{T,F} that takes one or more subjects (members of some domain Ω\OmegaΩ) and assigns to them all either true TTT or false FFF.

Predicates are typically denoted with capital letters like PPP, QQQ, and RRR. Subjects that are known are given lowercase letters like aaa, bbb, and ccc, unless there is something more reasonable to pick like hhh for Hypatia. Subjects whose values are unknown or arbitrary are denoted with lowercase xxx, yyy, zzz, etc.

The definition of predicate above is much more complicated than it needs to be; this is so that we can take the central idea (a function) and continue using it throughout the book. You know a function: an assigment f(x)f(x)f(x) that gives every input xxx exactly one output f(x)f(x)f(x). We write f:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y to signify that fff is a function whose inputs are elements of the set XXX and whose outputs are elements of the set YYY.

So, in the above definition, the predicate PPP is a function that takes a subject, a member of the set Ω\OmegaΩ, and assigns it exactly one truth value.

(Take note that propositions, which you studied in the last chapter, may be regarded as constant predicates – functions whose value is the same regardless of the input, like f(x)=3f(x)=3f(x)=3.)

Examples. Letting W(x)W(x)W(x) be the predicate "xxx is a woman" on the domain of humans and hhh stand for Hypatia, W(h)W(h)W(h) is the statement “Hypatia is a woman.” Since this statement is true, the function WWW assigns TTT to hhh.

Let P(x)P(x)P(x) be the predicate “x+3=5x + 3 = 5x+3=5” on the domain Z\mathbf{Z}Z and let Q(x,y)Q(x,y)Q(x,y) be the predicate "xxx orbits yyy" on the domain of celestial objects in the sky. The statement P(2)P(2)P(2) is true, but P(3)P(3)P(3) is false. If eee stands for the earth and sss for the sun, then Q(s,e)Q(s,e)Q(s,e) is false but Q(e,s)Q(e,s)Q(e,s) is true.

A predicate, once evaluated to a subject, is a statement. Therefore, these statements may be combined into compound statements using the logical connectives we have just studied.

Examples. As before let P(x)P(x)P(x) be the predicate “x+3=5x + 3 = 5x+3=5” on the domain Z\mathbf{Z}Z and let Q(x,y)Q(x,y)Q(x,y) be the predicate "xxx orbits yyy" on the domain of celestial objects in the sky, where eee stands for the earth and sss for the sun.

The statements P(2)∨Q(s,e)P(2) \vee Q(s,e)P(2)∨Q(s,e), ¬P(3)\neg P(3)¬P(3), and Q(s,e)→P(2)Q(s,e) \to P(2)Q(s,e)→P(2) are true.

The statements P(2)∧Q(s,e)P(2) \wedge Q(s,e)P(2)∧Q(s,e) and P(2)→Q(s,e)P(2) \to Q(s,e)P(2)→Q(s,e) ae false.

3.2 Quantifiers

This is all well and good, you think, but what about the statement “All women are mortal”? How can we make “all women” the subject of a statement?

Quantifiers allow us to say that a predicate is true for all, or for at least one undetermined, object in its domain.

Definition 3.2.1 Let P(x)P(x)P(x) be a predicate. The universal statement ∀xP(x)\forall x P(x)∀xP(x) says that P(x)P(x)P(x) is true for all xxx in its domain. The symbol ∀\forall∀ (“for all”) is called the universal quantifier.

Example. The domain is very important. If P(x)P(x)P(x) is the predicate "xxx takes discrete math" then ∀xP(x)\forall x P(x)∀xP(x) – “Everyone takes discrete math” – is true on the domain of computer science students at Coastal Carolina, but not, say, on the domain of all people in South Carolina.

Definition 3.2.2 Let P(x)P(x)P(x) be a predicate. The existential statement ∃xP(x)\exists x P(x)∃xP(x) says that P(x)P(x)P(x) is true for at least one xxx in its domain. The symbol ∃\exists∃ (“there exists”) is called the existential quantifier.

Example. Again let P(x)P(x)P(x) be the predicate "xxx takes discrete math". The existential statement ∃xP(x)\exists x P(x)∃xP(x) says “Someone takes discrete math.” This is now true for people in South Carolina – pick a student at Coastal, or Clemson, or USC – but not true on the domain of dogs. Wouldn’t that be cute, though?

The statement operated on by a quantifier is called its scope. Without parentheses, a quantifier is considered to apply only to the statement it is next to and no others.

Examples. Let P(x)P(x)P(x) be the predicate "xxx takes discrete math" and Q(x)Q(x)Q(x) be the statement "xxx is a math major".

  • The statement ∃x(P(x)∧Q(x))\exists x (P(x) \wedge Q(x))∃x(P(x)∧Q(x)) means “There is someone who is taking discrete math and is a math major.” Both PPP and QQQ apply to the same xxx.
  • The statement ∃xP(x)∧∃xQ(x)\exists x P(x) \wedge \exists x Q(x)∃xP(x)∧∃xQ(x) says “Someone is taking discrete math and someone is a math major.” The subjects of PPP and QQQ are possibly different.
  • The expression ∃xP(x)∧Q(x)\exists x P(x) \wedge Q(x)∃xP(x)∧Q(x) is not a statement at all, because Q(x)Q(x)Q(x) is not a statement. It needs either a quantifier, or for xxx to refer to a specific, known member of the domain.

There are two important quantified statements: “All PPP's are QQQ's” and "Some PPP is a QQQ". These statements are all over the place in mathematics. We like to characterize mathematical objects by saying all objects of one type also belong to another; or, by saying we can find an object of one type that is another type.

In “All PPP's are QQQ's”, the word “all” suggests that the universal quantifier is appropriate. What connective should be used to combine the predicates? Observe that the statement ∀x(P(x)∧Q(x))\forall x (P(x) \wedge Q(x))∀x(P(x)∧Q(x)) says that every xxx is both a PPP and a QQQ. This isn’t what we mean to say; we mean to say if something is a PPP then it will also be a QQQ. So, the correct rendering of “All PPP's are QQQ's” is ∀x(P(x)→Q(x))\forall x (P(x) \to Q(x))∀x(P(x)→Q(x)).

For the statement “Some PPP's are QQQ's”, we mean to say that there is an object that is at once a PPP and a QQQ. Therefore, this time the conjunction is appropriate: we write ∃x[P(x)∧Q(x)]\exists x [P(x) \wedge Q(x)]∃x[P(x)∧Q(x)].

Statement Implementation
“All PPP's are QQQ's” ∀x(P(x)→Q(x))\forall x (P(x) \to Q(x))∀x(P(x)→Q(x))
“Some PPP's are QQQ's” ∃x(P(x)∧Q(x))\exists x (P(x) \wedge Q(x))∃x(P(x)∧Q(x))

Finally, what is to be done with statements with two or more subjects? The ordering of the quantifiers matters. Here are the four possible combinations of universal and existential quantifiers for two subjects, as well as a diagram corresponding to each.

Examples. Let R(x,y)R(x,y)R(x,y) be the predicate "xxx and yyy are classmates" over the domain of students at some school. Note that, in this case, the order of the subjects does not affect the truth of the statement.

The statement ∃xyR(x,y)\exists xy R(x,y)∃xyR(x,y) means “There are two students who are classmates.” In other words, there is at least one student who is paired with at least one other student. Some writers say ∃x∃yR(x,y)\exists x \exists y R(x,y)∃x∃yR(x,y) instead, but when the quantifiers are the same we will “collapse” the notation.



Figure. On the left, one object is paired with one object (existential-existential). On the right, one object is paired with many objects (existential-universal).

The statement ∃x∀yR(x,y)\exists x \forall y R(x,y)∃x∀yR(x,y) means “There is a student who is classmates with every student.” We have one student who (somehow!) is classmates with the entire student body.

The statement ∀x∃yR(x,y)\forall x \exists y R(x,y)∀x∃yR(x,y) means “Every student has a classmate.” Notice that their classmate need not be the same person. If we quantify universally first, then each existential object may be different. In the preceding example, we quantified existentially first, so that one person was classmates with everybody.



Figure. On the left, many objects are each paired with an object (universal-existential). On the right, many objects are paired with many objects (universal-universal).

The statement ∀xyR(x,y)\forall xy R(x,y)∀xyR(x,y) means “Every student is classmates with every other student.” Every object in our domain is paired up with every other object in the domain, including themselves! (Don’t think too hard about that for this example.)

3.3 Inferences and equivalences for quantifiers

Quantifiers evaluated on a predicate are statements, since they are functions to {T,F}\{T,F\}{T,F}. Therefore, some quantified statements imply others, and some pairs imply each other. In this section we will learn a few important rules for quantifiers, before finally proving that our opening statement about Hypatia is indeed a tautology.

Theorem 3.3.1 (DeMorgan’s laws) Let P(x)P(x)P(x) be a predicate. Then ¬∀xP(x)≡∃x¬P(x)\neg \forall x P(x) \equiv \exists x \neg P(x)¬∀xP(x)≡∃x¬P(x) and ¬∃xP(x)≡∀x¬P(x)\neg \exists x P(x) \equiv \forall x \neg P(x)¬∃xP(x)≡∀x¬P(x).

Does that name look familiar? Here is our second application of DeMorgan’s laws. (The third will appear in the exercises.) You will see how they are used in the proof.

Proof. Consider the universal statement ∀xP(x)\forall x P(x)∀xP(x) on the domain Ω={x1,x2,…xn}\Omega = \{x_1, x_2, \ldots x_n\}Ω={x1​,x2​,…xn​}. We may rewrite ∀xP(x)=P(x1)∧P(x2)∧⋯∧P(xn)\forall x P(x) = P(x_1) \wedge P(x_2) \wedge \cdots \wedge P(x_n)∀xP(x)=P(x1​)∧P(x2​)∧⋯∧P(xn​)
and ∃xP(x)=P(x1)∨P(x2)∨⋯∨P(xn).\exists x P(x) = P(x_1) \vee P(x_2) \vee \cdots \vee P(x_n).∃xP(x)=P(x1​)∨P(x2​)∨⋯∨P(xn​).
Therefore, ¬∀xP(x)=¬(P(x1)∧P(x2)∧⋯∧P(xn)).\neg \forall x P(x) = \neg (P(x_1) \wedge P(x_2) \wedge \cdots \wedge P(x_n)).¬∀xP(x)=¬(P(x1​)∧P(x2​)∧⋯∧P(xn​)).
Using DeMorgan’s law, ¬∀xP(x)=¬P(x1)∨¬P(x2)∨⋯∨¬P(xn)),\neg \forall x P(x) = \neg P(x_1) \vee \neg P(x_2) \vee \cdots \vee \neg P(x_n)),¬∀xP(x)=¬P(x1​)∨¬P(x2​)∨⋯∨¬P(xn​)),
which is the same as the statement ∃x¬P(x)\exists x \neg P(x)∃x¬P(x).
That ¬∃xP(x)≡∀x¬P(x)\neg \exists x P(x) \equiv \forall x \neg P(x)¬∃xP(x)≡∀x¬P(x) may be proven in the same way. □\square□

The idea is that a universal statement is a “big conjunction” and an existential statement is a “big disjunction.” The proof follows from the DeMorgan’s laws you learned in the preceding chapter .

The next two theorems deal with how universal and existential statements may imply one another.

Theorem 3.3.2 (Universal instantiation) If aaa is a member of the domain of the predicate PPP, then ∀xP(x)⇒P(a)\forall x P(x) \Rightarrow P(a)∀xP(x)⇒P(a).

Proof. If PPP is true for every member of its domain and aaa is a member of said domain, PPP must be true for aaa. □\square□

Theorem 3.3.3 (Existential generalization) If aaa is a member of the domain of the predicate PPP, then P(a)⇒∃xP(x)P(a) \Rightarrow \exists x P(x)P(a)⇒∃xP(x).

Proof. Let aaa be in the domain of PPP. If P(a)P(a)P(a) is true, then PPP is true for some member of its domain. □\square□

There are two comments to make about these two theorems. First, universal generalization and existential instantiation are not valid:

Examples. “I was able to easily pay off my college loans, therefore everyone can” is an example of invalid universal generalization.

“Someone in this room killed the wealthy magnate, so it must have been you!” is an example of invalid existential instantiation.

Finally, transitivity gives us that a universal statement implies an existential one: ∀xP(x)⇒P(a)⇒∃xP(x)\forall x P(x) \Rightarrow P(a) \Rightarrow \exists x P(x)∀xP(x)⇒P(a)⇒∃xP(x).

We are ready to prove our tautology is, in fact, a tautology. Remember that the statement was “If Hypatia is a woman and all women are mortal, then Hypatia is mortal.”

We have seen that “Hypatia is a woman” may be rendered as W(h)W(h)W(h) for the predicate W(x)W(x)W(x) being "xxx is a woman" and hhh being Hypatia. Likewise, “Hypatia is mortal” could be rendered M(h)M(h)M(h) where M(x)M(x)M(x) is "xxx is mortal". Finally, the statement “All women are mortal” would be ∀x(W(x)→M(x))\forall x (W(x) \to M(x))∀x(W(x)→M(x)).

Theorem 3.3.4 The statement [P(a)∧∀x(P(x)→Q(x))]→Q(a)[P(a) \wedge \forall x (P(x) \to Q(x))] \to Q(a)[P(a)∧∀x(P(x)→Q(x))]→Q(a) is a tautology.

We have changed our labeling to the more standard PPP, QQQ, and aaa to emphasize that this statement is always true no matter what we are talking about.

Proof. Suppose that for some predicate PPP and some aaa in the domain of PPP that P(a)P(a)P(a) is true, and that for some predicate QQQ the statement ∀x(P(x)→Q(x))\forall x (P(x) \to Q(x))∀x(P(x)→Q(x)) is true.

By universal instantiation, ∀x(P(x)→Q(x))\forall x (P(x) \to Q(x))∀x(P(x)→Q(x)) means that P(a)→Q(a)P(a) \to Q(a)P(a)→Q(a) is true.

By modus ponens on P(a)P(a)P(a) and P(a)→Q(a)P(a) \to Q(a)P(a)→Q(a), we know Q(a)Q(a)Q(a) must be true.

Therefore, [P(a)∧∀x(P(x)→Q(x))]→Q(a)[P(a) \wedge \forall x (P(x) \to Q(x))] \to Q(a)[P(a)∧∀x(P(x)→Q(x))]→Q(a) is always true. □\square□

Takeaways

  • If we need to communicate that two statements talk about the same thing, propositional logic won’t cut it: we need predicates.
  • A predicate is a function that takes an input and returns true or false. The predicate itself isn’t a statement, but it is once it’s evaluated on a subject.
  • A quantifier yields a statement that a predicate is true for some, or all, objects in its domain.
  • "Every – is a – " is a universal conditional statement. "Some – is a – " is an existential conjunction.
  • A universal statement implies a specific one, which implies an existential statement.
  • The negation of a universal statement is an existential statement and vice-versa.

Proofs
