The second two cards give the second day’s activities. However, we have double-counted by 2!2!2! since there are 2!2!2! ways to arrange those cards, and we don’t care which is first. Likewise with the second two cards.

Theorem 12.1.1 Take a multiset from [k][k][k] where rir_iri​ is the multiplicity of i∈[k]i \in [k]i∈[k], and the sum of the rir_iri​ is nnn. Consider a function f:Ω→[k]f:\Omega \to [k]f:Ω→[k] such that the number of x∈Ωx \in \Omegax∈Ω such that f(x)=if(x) = if(x)=i is rir_iri​. The number of such functions is given by the multinomial coefficient (nr1,r2,…,rk)=n!r1!r2!⋯rk! {{n}\choose{r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_k}} = \frac{n!}{r_1!r_2!\cdots r_k!} (r1​,r2​,…,rk​n​)=r1​!r2​!⋯rk​!n!​

Example. How many distinguishable arrangements are there of the word ARRANGEMENT?

“Distinguishable” means that we can tell the difference in the arrangements. For example, there are two R’s in the word. If we call them R1 and R2, there is no difference between A(R1)(R2)ANGEMENT and A(R2)(R1)ANGEMENT.

There are 777 different letters in the word ARRANGEMENT. If we number the 111111 characters in the word, then we are trying to count the number of functions f:{1,2,3,…,11}→{A,R,N,G,E,M,T} f: \{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 11\} \to \{A, R, N, G, E, M, T\} f:{1,2,3,…,11}→{A,R,N,G,E,M,T} such that rxr_xrx​ characters are the letter xxx, rA=rR=rE=rN=2, r_A = r_R = r_E = r_N = 2, rA​=rR​=rE​=rN​=2, and rG=rM=rT=1. r_G = r_M = r_T = 1.rG​=rM​=rT​=1. By the preceding theorem there are (112,2,2,1,2,1,1)=11!2!2!2!1!2!1!1!=2,494,800 {{11}\choose{2,2,2,1,2,1,1}} = \frac{11!}{2!2!2!1!2!1!1!} = 2,494,800 (2,2,2,1,2,1,111​)=2!2!2!1!2!1!1!11!​=2,494,800 total distinguishable arrangements of the word.

That explanation was perhaps a bit painstaking to make clear the viewpoint of counting functions based on a multiset, but there is a cleaner path to the answer. There are 11!11!11! ways to arrange all the letters; however, we have double-counted by the 2!2!2! arrangements of the A’s, R’s, N’s, and E’s, and so we divide by 2!2!2! four times.

12.2 Multinomial theorems

Observe that when k=2k=2k=2, a multinomial coefficient is exactly a binomial coefficient with r1=rr_1=rr1​=r and r2=n−rr_2=n-rr2​=n−r. When k=3k=3k=3 we call the numbers trinomial coefficients and thereafter typically say “multinomial coefficients”.

Accordingly, theorems about binomial coefficients generalize to multinomial coefficients. For example, the trinomial coefficients exhibit a similar recurrence relation.

Theorem 12.2.1 Let nnn be a positive integer and r1,r2,r3r_1, r_2, r_3r1​,r2​,r3​ be positive integers summing to nnn. Then, (nr1,r2,r3)=(n−1r1−1,r2,r3)+(n−1r1,r2−1,r3)+(n−1r1,r2,r3−1).{{n}\choose{r_1, r_2, r_3}} = {{n-1}\choose{r_1-1,r_2,r_3}} + {{n-1}\choose{r_1,r_2-1,r_3}} + {{n-1}\choose{r_1,r_2,r_3-1}}.(r1​,r2​,r3​n​)=(r1​−1,r2​,r3​n−1​)+(r1​,r2​−1,r3​n−1​)+(r1​,r2​,r3​−1n−1​).

There is, accordingly, a multinomial theorem:

Theorem 12.2.2 Let nnn and kkk be positive integers. Then (x1+x2+⋯+xk)n=∑(nr1,r2,…,rk)x1r1x2r2⋯xkrk. (x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_k)^n = \sum {{n}\choose{r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_k}} x_1^{r_1} x_2^{r_2} \cdots x_k^{r_k}.(x1​+x2​+⋯+xk​)n=∑(r1​,r2​,…,rk​n​)x1r1​​x2r2​​⋯xkrk​​.

This theorem tells us that when we expand the polynomial (x1+x2+⋯+xk)n(x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_k)^n(x1​+x2​+⋯+xk​)n,

  • there are C(k−1+n,n)C(k-1+n, n)C(k−1+n,n) different terms (one for each multiset of cardinality nnn from {x1,x2,…,xk}\{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_k\}{x1​,x2​,…,xk​}–careful with the notation here because the nnn has switched places!),
  • each of which is multiplied by the appropriate multinomial coefficient.

Example. There are C(15,10)=3,003C(15,10) = 3,003C(15,10)=3,003 terms of the polynomial (a+b+c+d+e+f)10(a+b+c+d+e+f)^{10}(a+b+c+d+e+f)10. Obviously we will not list them all. The a5bc2efa^5bc^2efa5bc2ef term has the coefficient (105,1,2,0,1,1)=10!5!1!2!0!1!1!=15,120. {{10}\choose{5,1,2,0,1,1}} = \frac{10!}{5!1!2!0!1!1!} = 15,120.(5,1,2,0,1,110​)=5!1!2!0!1!1!10!​=15,120.

Takeaways

  • Counting multisets (discussed in the preceding chapter) counts the number of ways to distribute rrr objects into nnn types. Once you have chosen a multiset, you now must choose which objects will be which type according to the distribution. Multinomial coefficients count the number of ways to do so.
  • Multinomial coefficients are generalizations of binomial coefficients for k>2k>2k>2, so many theorems “come up,” including the recurrence relation and the multinomial theorem.

Chapter 12 problems

13. Probability

Review.

  • Chapter 9: Enumeration and basic counting principles

The time has come to end our short tour through combinatorics with a conversation about probability, the study of random phenomena. There is a lot more to say about both topics, but that’s for other books to do.

13.1 Introduction to probability

Speaking very loosely, an event’s probability is the “chance” it will occur. There are two kinds of probabilities: empirical probability, the proportion of times an event occurred over a number of trials; and theoretical probability, the proportion of times an event should occur over the long run. We assign theoretical probabilities according to mathematical principles so that the long-run empirical probability tends towards the theoretical probability. It will not surprise you to learn, then, that probability is a function of sets.

Definition 13.1.1 Let EEE be an event contained in the universe Ω\OmegaΩ (in probability-theoretic contexts the universe is called the sample space). If every outcome of EEE is equally likely, then the probability of EEE is P(E)=∣E∣∣Ω∣.P(E) = \frac{|E|}{|\Omega|}.P(E)=∣Ω∣∣E∣​.

To brush some interesting technical details away, we are assuming that EEE and Ω\OmegaΩ are finite sets and doing discrete probability with something called the “counting measure.” There are other ways to measure sets, and those measures have associated probabilities as well; but this is beyond our scope.

Example. Two dice are rolled. They are distinguishable; you may suppose one is red and the other is blue, or that the person rolling kept track of which was rolled first. The sample space of 363636 possible sums of the two dice is tabulated below.

1 2 3 4 5 6
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
2 3 4 5 6 7 8
3 4 5 6 7 8 9
4 5 6 7 8 9 10
5 6 7 8 9 10 11
6 7 8 9 10 11 12

Let EEE be the event that the sum is prime and let FFF be event that the first roll was even. (You may choose the row or column to be the first roll; it won’t matter in this case.) Then, P(E)=1536P(E) = \frac{15}{36}P(E)=3615​ and P(F)=1836.P(F) = \frac{18}{36}.P(F)=3618​. Check these counts yourself.

Sometimes it is desirable to know how one event affects another. For example: does the first roll being even make it more or less likely that the sum will be prime? Or is there no effect? Conditional probability answers this question for us.

Definition 13.1.2 Let EEE and FFF be events. The conditional probability of EEE given that FFF is known to occur is P(E∣F)=∣E∩F∣∣F∣. P(E|F) = \frac{|E \cap F|}{|F|}.P(E∣F)=∣F∣∣E∩F∣​.

A very good interpretation of the above definition is that the original sample space is replaced with or “localized” to be FFF.

Example. Suppose the rectangle below is a dartboard. We have two players: a novice who throws the dart perfectly randomly, or someone with a little more experience who will always land the dart within quadrilateral FFF. Who is more likely to land in the target EEE? The more experienced player will land in EEE more often on average. In probabilistic notation, P(E∣F)>P(E)P(E|F) > P(E)P(E∣F)>P(E).



The set E is visualized as a small circle in the middle of a large rectangle, enclosed in a smaller quadrilateral F.

Example. Revisiting our dice question, does the first roll being even make it more or less likely the sum will be prime?

1 2 3 4 5 6
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
2 3 4 5 6 7 8
3 4 5 6 7 8 9
4 5 6 7 8 9 10
5 6 7 8 9 10 11
6 7 8 9 10 11 12

There are 181818 outcomes where the first roll is even. Counting, we see 777 outcomes where the sum is prime and the first roll is even. (Check this.) By definition, P(E∣F)=718=1436, P(E|F) = \frac{7}{18} = \frac{14}{36},P(E∣F)=187​=3614​, which is less than P(E)=15/36.P(E) = 15/36.P(E)=15/36. So, prime sums are less likely when the first roll is even (so, more likely when the first roll is odd).

13.2 Algebraic rules

The probability that at least one of EEE or FFF occurs is denoted P(E∪F)P(E \cup F)P(E∪F), and the probability that both events occur is denoted P(E∩F)P(E \cap F)P(E∩F).

Theorem 13.2.1 If EEE and FFF are events, then P(E∩F)=P(E)P(F∣E)=P(F)P(E∣F)P(E \cap F) = P(E)P(F|E) = P(F)P(E|F)P(E∩F)=P(E)P(F∣E)=P(F)P(E∣F) and P(E∪F)=P(E)+P(F)−P(E∩F).P(E \cup F) = P(E) + P(F) - P(E \cap F).P(E∪F)=P(E)+P(F)−P(E∩F).

Proof. Fundamental counting principles, together with the observation that one of EEE or FFF has an effect on the other. □\square□

Definition 13.2.2 If P(E∩F)=0P(E \cap F) = 0P(E∩F)=0, the events EEE and FFF are disjoint.

Example. The events “the first roll is odd” and “the first roll is even” are disjoint since they cannot both happen at the same time.

Theorem 13.2.3 The following are equivalent.

  • P(E∩F)=P(E)P(F)P(E \cap F) = P(E)P(F)P(E∩F)=P(E)P(F)
  • P(E∣F)=P(E)P(E|F) = P(E)P(E∣F)=P(E)
  • P(F∣E)=P(F)P(F|E) = P(F)P(F∣E)=P(F)
  • EEE and FFF are independent. (This is a definition of the other three bullets.)

Example. Any event involving just the first die and any event involving just the second die will be independent.

Example. Again with the dice:

1 2 3 4 5 6
1 2 3 4 5 6 7
2 3 4 5 6 7 8
3 4 5 6 7 8 9
4 5 6 7 8 9 10
5 6 7 8 9 10 11
6 7 8 9 10 11 12

The probability that a sum is prime and a first roll is even is, by counting, P(E∩F)=736.P(E \cap F) = \frac{7}{36}.P(E∩F)=367​. We may also use the multiplication rule to calculate this probability: P(E∩F)=P(F)P(E∣F)=1836718=736. P(E \cap F) = P(F)P(E|F) = \frac{18}{36}\frac{7}{18} = \frac{7}{36}.P(E∩F)=P(F)P(E∣F)=3618​187​=367​.

The probability that a sum is prime or a first roll is even is, again by counting first, P(E∪F)=2636.P(E \cup F) = \frac{26}{36}.P(E∪F)=3626​. We may also use the addition rule: P(E∪F)=P(E)+P(F)−P(E∩F)=1536+1836−736=2636. P(E \cup F) = P(E) + P(F) - P(E \cap F) = \frac{15}{36} + \frac{18}{36} - \frac{7}{36} = \frac{26}{36}.P(E∪F)=P(E)+P(F)−P(E∩F)=3615​+3618​−367​=3626​.

Takeaways

  • Probability is in some sense the study of relative measures of sets.
  • When the elements of the sample space can be enumerated, this is usually the correct approach.
  • If not, the addition and multiplication principles lift to rules about probability (with the added wrinkle of conditional probability).

Chapter 13 problems

14. Boolean matrices

Review.

  • Chapter 1: Union, intersection, and complement
  • Chapter 2: Disjunction, conjunction, and negation
  • Chapter 3: Predicates

Relations allow us to mathematically encode various relatonships between sets. There are many such relationships we may be interested in: graphs, functions, equivalences, and orderings. But before we tell that story, we have to tell this one: the story of Boolean matrices.

14.1 Matrices and Boolean algebras

Did you notice at the beginning of the book that logic and set theory were incredibly similar to one another? They are indeed different implementations of the same idea, Boolean algebra. As you read the following technical details, just keep in mind that a Boolean algebra is formalizing the relationships between logical connectives and set operations.

Definition 14.1.1 A bit is an element of the set {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1} together with commutative binary operations join ∨\vee∨ and meet ∧\wedge∧ and unary operation complement ¬\neg¬ such that a∨b={0a=b=01otherwise, a \vee b = \begin{cases} 0 & a=b=0 \\ 1 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}, a∨b={01​a=b=0otherwise​, a∧b={1a=b=10otherwise, a \wedge b = \begin{cases} 1 & a=b=1 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}, a∧b={10​a=b=1otherwise​, and ¬a={1a=00a=1. \neg a = \begin{cases} 1 & a=0 \\ 0 & a=1 \end{cases}.¬a={10​a=0a=1​.

Definition 14.1.2 A Boolean algebra is a set A\mathcal{A}A together with commutative binary operations ∨\vee∨ and ∧\wedge∧ such that a∨0=a,a∧1=a, a \vee 0 = a, \qquad a \wedge 1 = a,a∨0=a,a∧1=a, a∨(b∧c)=(a∨b)∧(a∨c),a \vee (b \wedge c) = (a \vee b) \wedge (a \vee c),a∨(b∧c)=(a∨b)∧(a∨c), and a∧(b∨c)=(a∧b)∨(a∧c), a \wedge (b \vee c) = (a \wedge b) \vee (a \wedge c),a∧(b∨c)=(a∧b)∨(a∧c), and a unary operation ¬\neg¬ such that a∨¬a=1,a∧¬a=0. a \vee \neg a = 1, \qquad a \wedge \neg a = 0.a∨¬a=1,a∧¬a=0.

Examples. The set {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1} is the smallest non-degenerate Boolean algebra. Here are two other Boolean algebras. You will be asked to verify that these are Boolean algebras in the exercises.

  • Let S\mathcal{S}S be a finite collection of statements formed from a set of nnn distinct statement letters, and let S∗\mathcal{S^*}S∗ be the set of statements in S\mathcal{S}S together with all possible conjunctions, disjunctions, and negations of those statements. (As an exercise, prove that the tautology TTT and the contradiction FFF must be in S∗\mathcal{S^*}S∗.) Then S∗\mathcal{S^*}S∗ is the smallest Boolean algebra containing S\mathcal{S}S.
  • Let E\mathcal{E}E be a finite collection of subsets of a set XXX. Let E∗\mathcal{E^*}E∗ be the set of all finite intersections, unions, and complements of those sets. (You can prove that XXX and ∅\varnothing∅ must be in E∗\mathcal{E^*}E∗.) Then E∗\mathcal{E^*}E∗ is the smallest Boolean algebra containing EEE.

Loosely speaking, a matrix is a rectangular array of data. This data can be anything with an algebraic structure, including bits and numbers. While matrices serve as a convenient way to store information, they also have applicatons in solving systems of linear equations and in encoding relations and functions. It is this last usage that we are the most interested. Before you read the definition below remember [m]={1,2,…,m}[m]=\{1, 2, \ldots, m\}[m]={1,2,…,m} when mmm is a positive integer.

Definition 14.1.3 An m×nm \times nm×n matrix is a function A:[m]×[n]→XA:[m]\times[n] \to XA:[m]×[n]→X where XXX is a set with certain algebraic structure (for us, bits or numbers) such that the entry A(i,j)A(i,j)A(i,j) in the iii-th row and jjj-th column is written Ai,jA_{i,j}Ai,j​. To specify the elements that belong to the matrix we sometimes write A=(Ai,j)A=(A_{i,j})A=(Ai,j​). We say AAA has mmm rows and nnn columns and can represent the matrix visually as A=(A1,1A1,2⋯A1,nA2,1A2,2⋯A2,n⋱Am,1Am,2⋯Am,n). A = \left( \begin{array}{cccc} A_{1,1} & A_{1,2} & \cdots & A_{1,n} \\ A_{2,1} & A_{2,2} & \cdots & A_{2,n} \\ & & \ddots & \\ A_{m,1} & A_{m,2} & \cdots & A_{m,n} \end{array} \right). A=⎝⎜⎜⎛​A1,1​A2,1​Am,1​​A1,2​A2,2​Am,2​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​A1,n​A2,n​Am,n​​⎠⎟⎟⎞​.

More than you wanted to know: The desired properties of the set XXX are the presence of an operation playing the role of addition and an operation playing the role of multiplication, such that subtraction is possible and otherwise these operations satisfy all the usual properties that addition and multiplication do. Such a structure is called a ring. The integers Z\mathbf{Z}Z are the classic example as the smallest ring containing all the elements of N\mathbf{N}N, and the Boolean algebra {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1} is another. If all the non-zero elements of the ring can be inverted – i.e., you can divide as well – the ring is called a field and then matrix division may be possible as well.

Definition 14.1.4 A Boolean matrix is a matrix whose entries are bits.

Examples. Consider the Boolean matrix A=(101011). A = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{array} \right).A=(10​01​11​). This is a matrix with 222 rows and 333 columns, so we would say it is a 2×32 \times 32×3 matrix. The entry A1,3=1A_{1,3}=1A1,3​=1, the entry A2,1=0A_{2,1}=0A2,1​=0, and the entry A3,1A_{3,1}A3,1​ does not exist for this matrix.

What follows are some worthwhile definitions for studying matrices and relations.

Definition 14.1.5 An m×nm \times nm×n matrix is square if m=nm=nm=n.

Definition 14.1.6 Let AAA be a square n×nn \times nn×n matrix. The entries Ai,jA_{i,j}Ai,j​ where i=ji=ji=j are called diagonal entries and entries that are not diagonal are off-diagonal entries.

Definition 14.1.7 A square matrix whose only nonzero entries are diagonal is a diagonal matrix.

Definition 14.1.8 The identity matrix InI_nIn​ of dimension nnn is the n×nn\times nn×n diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are all 111.

Examples. The matrix A=(101011100) A = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0\end{array} \right) A=⎝⎛​101​010​110​⎠⎞​ is square but not diagonal, the matrix B=(100010000) B =\left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0\end{array} \right)B=⎝⎛​100​010​000​⎠⎞​ is diagonal but not I3I_3I3​, and I3=(100010001).I_3=\left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right).I3​=⎝⎛​100​010​001​⎠⎞​.

Definition 14.1.9 Let AAA and BBB both be m×nm \times nm×n Boolean matrices. We say A≤BA \le BA≤B if ai,j≤bi,ja_{i,j} \le b_{i,j}ai,j​≤bi,j​ (as numbers) for all (i,j)∈[m]×[n](i,j) \in [m]\times[n](i,j)∈[m]×[n]. Equivalently, we can say that A≤BA \le BA≤B if BBB never has a 000 in a position where AAA has a 111.

Example. For instance, (100110)≤(101111) \left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0\\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0\end{array} \right) \le \left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0\\ 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1\end{array} \right)⎝⎛​101​010​⎠⎞​≤⎝⎛​111​011​⎠⎞​ but (100110)≰(010111).\left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0\\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0\end{array} \right) \not\le \left( \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1\\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1\end{array} \right).⎝⎛​101​010​⎠⎞​​≤⎝⎛​001​111​⎠⎞​.

14.2 Basic matrix operations

In this section we will explore basic operations involving matrices: meet, join, complement, and transposition. Multiplication requires enough work to necessitate its own section.

Definition 14.2.1 Let AAA and BBB be m×nm\times nm×n matrices. Their meet (or join) is the m×nm\times nm×n matrix A∧B=(Ai,j∧Bi,j)A \wedge B = (A_{i,j} \wedge B_{i,j})A∧B=(Ai,j​∧Bi,j​) (or A∨B=(Ai,j∨Bi,j)A \vee B=(A_{i,j} \vee B_{i,j})A∨B=(Ai,j​∨Bi,j​)) whose i,ji,ji,j-th entry is the meet (join) of the i,ji,ji,j-th entries of AAA and BBB.

Examples. (010101)∧(001011)=(000001) \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) \wedge \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{array} \right) = \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0& 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) (01​10​01​)∧(00​01​11​)=(00​00​01​)

(010101)∨(001011)=(011111) \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) \vee \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{array} \right) = \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{array} \right) (01​10​01​)∨(00​01​11​)=(01​11​11​)

Definition 14.2.2 Let A=[Ai,j]A=[A_{i,j}]A=[Ai,j​] be a m×nm\times nm×n Boolean matrix. Its complement is the m×nm\times nm×n Boolean matrix ¬A=(¬Ai,j)\neg A = (\neg A_{i,j})¬A=(¬Ai,j​).

Example.

¬(001011)=(110100) \neg \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{array} \right) = \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \right) ¬(00​01​11​)=(11​10​00​)

The last operation we need to look at in this section is transposition, where a matrix’s rows and columns are interchanged.

Definition 14.2.3 Let A=(Ai,j)A=(A_{i,j})A=(Ai,j​) be a m×nm\times nm×n Boolean matrix. Its transpose is the n×mn \times mn×m Boolean matrix AT=(Aj,i)A^T = (A_{j,i})AT=(Aj,i​).

Example.
(111001)T=(110101) \left (\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array} \right)^T = \left (\begin{array}{ccc} 1&1&0 \\ 1&0&1 \end{array} \right)⎝⎛​110​101​⎠⎞​T=(11​10​01​)

14.3 Multiplication of Boolean matrices

Multiplication of matrices in general, and Boolean matrices in particular, is not as straightforward as you would hope at first. As we will see in the next chapter, each Boolean matrix represents a relation, and multiplication of matrices should correspond to a combination of relations.

Real matrices, i.e. matrices with values in R\mathbf{R}R, correspond to linear transformations, functions that rotate, stretch, or shear space. Multiplication of real matrices corresponds to composition of these functions.

Definition 14.3.1 Let A=(A1A2…An)A = (\begin{array}{cccc}A_1 & A_2 & \ldots & A_n\end{array})A=(A1​​A2​​…​An​​) be a 1×n1\times n1×n Boolean row matrix and B=(B1B2…Bn)TB = (\begin{array}{cccc}B_1 & B_2 & \ldots & B_n\end{array})^TB=(B1​​B2​​…​Bn​​)T be a n×1n\times 1n×1 Boolean column matrix. Their Boolean dot product is the bit A⊙B=(A1∧B1)∨(A2∧B2)∨⋯∨(An∧Bn). A \odot B = (A_1 \wedge B_1) \vee (A_2 \wedge B_2) \vee \cdots \vee (A_n \wedge B_n).A⊙B=(A1​∧B1​)∨(A2​∧B2​)∨⋯∨(An​∧Bn​). We may also write this in “big vee” notation: A⊙B=⋁r=1n(Ai∧Bi). A \odot B = \bigvee_{r=1}^n (A_i \wedge B_i). A⊙B=r=1⋁n​(Ai​∧Bi​).

Example. Let A=(0101) A=\left(\begin{array}{cccc} 0 & 1 & 0 & 1\end{array}\right)A=(0​1​0​1​) and B=(1100).B=\left( \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{array} \right).B=⎝⎜⎜⎛​1100​⎠⎟⎟⎞​. Then,
A⊙B=(0∧1)∨(1∧1)∨(0∧0)∨(1∧0).A \odot B = (0 \wedge 1) \vee (1 \wedge 1) \vee (0 \wedge 0) \vee (1 \wedge 0).A⊙B=(0∧1)∨(1∧1)∨(0∧0)∨(1∧0). Evaluating each of the conjunctions, we have A⊙B=0∨1∨0∨0.A \odot B = 0 \vee 1 \vee 0 \vee 0.A⊙B=0∨1∨0∨0. Since A⊙BA \odot BA⊙B is a join with at least one 111, A⊙B=1.A \odot B = 1.A⊙B=1. In fact, A⊙BA\odot BA⊙B is only 111 because there is an entry (the second one) where both AiA_iAi​ and BiB_iBi​ are 1. If there are no such entries, the Boolean dot product will always be 0. This theorem is highly useful in quickly calculating Boolean products.

Theorem 14.3.2 Let A=(Ai)A=(A_i)A=(Ai​) be a 1×n1\times n1×n Boolean matrix and B=(Bi)B=(B_i)B=(Bi​) be a n×1n\times 1n×1 Boolean matrix. Their Boolean dot product A⊙BA \odot BA⊙B is 111 if and only if there exists an integer kkk such that AkA_kAk​ and BkB_kBk​ are both 111.

Reflect for a moment that this definition does not drop out of thin area, as most don’t. Suppose we have predicates A(i)A(i)A(i) and B(i)B(i)B(i) whose domains are both [n][n][n]. The Boolean dot product A⊙BA\odot BA⊙B is 1 if and only if there exists an object in the domain for which A(i)∧B(i)A(i) \wedge B(i)A(i)∧B(i) is true. As an example, let A(i)A(i)A(i) be the statement "iii is even" and B(i)B(i)B(i) be the statement “i≤2i \le 2i≤2”, both over the domain [4][4][4]. Then the above example answers the question, “Is there an element of [4][4][4] that is both even and less than or equal to 222?”

Definition 14.3.3 Let A=(Ai,j)A=(A_{i,j})A=(Ai,j​) be a m×km\times km×k Boolean matrix and B=(Bi,j)B=(B_{i,j})B=(Bi,j​) be a k×nk \times nk×n Boolean matrix. Their Boolean product is the m×nm\times nm×n matrix A⊙B=(⋁r=1k(Ai,r∧Br,j));A\odot B = \left( \bigvee_{r=1}^k (A_{i,r} \wedge B_{r,j})\right);A⊙B=(r=1⋁k​(Ai,r​∧Br,j​)); that is, the i,ji,ji,j-th entry of A⊙BA \odot BA⊙B is the Boolean dot product of the iii-th row of AAA with the jjj-th column of BBB.

Note that AAA must have exactly as many columns as BBB has rows, else the Boolean dot products will be undefined.

Example. Let A=(010110) A = \left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1\\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right)A=⎝⎛​001​110​⎠⎞​ and B=(110010). B = \left(\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{array}\right).B=(10​11​00​). Their Boolean product A⊙BA \odot BA⊙B is the matrix whose entries are the Boolean dot products of the appropriate rows of AAA with the corresponding columns of BBB.

For example, the entry in the first row and first column is (0∧1)∨(1∧0)=0∨0=0, (0 \wedge 1) \vee (1 \wedge 0) = 0 \vee 0 = 0,(0∧1)∨(1∧0)=0∨0=0, as evidenced by the fact that the first row (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) of AAA and the first column (1,0)T(1,0)^T(1,0)T of BBB do not have any 111's in the same spot. Meanwhile, the 1,21,21,2-th entry of the product is 111, because the first row and the second column both have a 111 in the second position. Here is the full product: A⊙B=(010010110) A \odot B = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 & 0 \end{array} \right) A⊙B=⎝⎛​001​111​000​⎠⎞​

As an exercise, compute B⊙AB \odot AB⊙A and verify that it is not equal to A⊙BA \odot BA⊙B.

From the logical perspective, a Boolean matrix is a family of statements. The Boolean product then gives a matrix whose entries answer the question, “Is there a subject for which the statement represented by this row and the statement represented by that column are both true simultaneously?”

Takeaways

  • A Boolean algebra is a structure that models the algebraic behavior of collections of sets, as well as statements. The simplest of these is the algebra {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1} of bits.
  • A Boolean matrix is an array of bits.
  • One can take the meet, join, and complement of a matrix just like one would take the meet, join, and complement of the corresponding bits.
  • We will see soon that products of Boolean matrices represent combinations of relations. In fact, we can already understand how Boolean matrices represent predicate statements quantified over finite domains.

Chapter 14 problems

15. Relations

Review.

  • Chapter 1: Sets, especially subsets and cartesian products
  • Chapter 2 and 3: Logic, particularly proofs relying on the emptiness of the empty set (e.g., “The empty set is a subset of any set.”)

As previously stated, a relation is a way to mathematically encode the idea of a relationship between objects. What does that mean? When we “encode” an idea mathematically, we are defining a mathematical object that captures the important data of that idea. Because the thing is now a mathematical object, we can do mathematics to it. If the thing has become an expression involving real numbers, it is now subject to algebra. If the thing has become a set, it is now subject to set operations, logic, proof, combinatorics, so on. One may imagine importing a package into a programming language so they have new objects to “play with” in that language.

In this chapter we will define relations, discuss various ways to represent them, and discuss some properties of interesting relations.

15.1 Basic notions and representation

Remember that the product X×YX \times YX×Y of two sets is the collection of all pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) whose first component is from XXX and whose second component is from YYY. Therefore, this is a good place to start thinking about connecting two sets.

Definition 15.1.1 Let XXX and YYY be sets. A relation RRR from XXX to YYY is any subset R⊆X×YR \subseteq X \times YR⊆X×Y. We say that XXX is the domain and YYY is the codomain of YYY. When (x,y)∈R(x,y) \in R(x,y)∈R, we say "xxx is related to yyy" and may write xRyxRyxRy.

Example. Let X={x,y,z}X = \{x,y,z\}X={x,y,z} and Y={1,2}Y=\{1,2\}Y={1,2}. One of the many relations from XXX to YYY is the set {(x,1),(x,2),(y,2)}. \{ (x,1), (x,2), (y,2) \}. {(x,1),(x,2),(y,2)}. We would say (for instance) that xxx is related to 111, or that zzz is related to nothing.

Some relations have their own symbols. We will be a little sloppy and sometimes identify the statement xRyxRyxRy with the relation itself.

Example. The relation Δ={(x,x)  ∣  x∈X}\Delta=\{(x,x) \;|\; x \in X\}Δ={(x,x)∣x∈X} is the relation of all pairs (x,y)∈X×X(x,y) \in X \times X(x,y)∈X×X where x=yx=yx=y. (When the domain and codomain of a relation are the same we say it is a relation on XXX.) This relation is called the diagonal relation on the set XXX. (Exercise: Figure out why.) It may be denoted with the symbol Δ\DeltaΔ (capital delta), or it may be denoted with the statement characterizing its elements. In other words, we might say “Consider the relation x=yx=yx=y on a set XXX.”

You have seen functions in algebra, or perhaps calculus, and we have used them in various definitions. In other words, a function f:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y is an assignment that pairs every element x∈Xx \in Xx∈X with a unique element f(x)∈Yf(x) \in Yf(x)∈Y. A function is a relation, subject to the extra criteria that every element of XXX is paired to exactly one element of YYY, whereas a relation can have elements of XXX related to many elements of YYY, or no elements of YYY.

If XXX and YYY are finite sets there are two convenient ways to represent a relations between XXX and YYY. Without loss of generality, label the elements of XXX as x1,x2,…,xmx_1, x_2, \ldots, x_mx1​,x2​,…,xm​ and those of YYY as y1,y2,…,yny_1, y_2, \ldots, y_ny1​,y2​,…,yn​. Consider that each element xi∈Xx_i \in Xxi​∈X induces the statement "xix_ixi​ is related to yjy_jyj​". Remembering that Boolean matrices encode families of statements, we may define the m×nm\times nm×n matrix MR=(mi,j) M_R = (m_{i,j})MR​=(mi,j​) where mi,j=1m_{i,j} = 1mi,j​=1 if and only if xix_ixi​ is related to yjy_jyj​.

Example. Earlier we had the relation {(x,1),(x,2),(y,2)} \{ (x,1), (x,2), (y,2) \} {(x,1),(x,2),(y,2)} from X={x,y,z}X = \{x,y,z\}X={x,y,z} to Y={1,2}Y=\{1,2\}Y={1,2}. There are many different matrices representing this relation depending on how the sets XXX and YYY are ordered. When there is an “obvious” ordering, say numerical or alphabetical, we will use that one. Under these orderings the matrix for the relation is (110100) \left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array} \right) ⎝⎛​100​110​⎠⎞​.

Consider a relation RRR on a set XXX (meaning domain and codomain are the same set). We can also represent RRR visually with something called a directed graph or digraph for short. From this perspective, the elements of XXX are called the vertices of the graph and the pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) in the relation are called edges or arrows. An arrow is drawn from one vertex to another if those vertices are related.

Example. Let X={a,b,c,d}X = \{a,b,c,d\}X={a,b,c,d}, and consider the relation R={(a,b),(a,d),(b,b),(b,c),(d,a)}. R = \{ (a,b), (a,d), (b,b), (b,c), (d,a) \}. R={(a,b),(a,d),(b,b),(b,c),(d,a)}. The directed graph for this relation is shown below.



Figure. The directed graph for the relation is shown.

It is possible to draw many graphs for one relation, so why can we say “the directed graph”? Observe that any graphs will have the same arrows between the same vertices. Two graphs for which there is a 1-1 correspondence that preserves the edges are isomorphic and are functionally the same. Therefore, we say “the” directed graph for a relation.

15.2 Properties of relations

As we study relations in the remaining chapters of this book there are a few properties that will make for valuable terminology. For the remainder of the chapter, every relation has the same domain and codomain.

Definition 15.2.1 A relation RRR on a set XXX is reflexive if every element is related to itself, in other words (x,x)∈R(x,x) \in R(x,x)∈R for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X. The pair (x,x)(x,x)(x,x) is a diagonal pair.

Definition 15.2.2 A relation RRR on a set XXX is antireflexive if no element is related to itself, in other words (x,x)∉R(x,x) \not\in R(x,x)​∈R for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X.

So a relation is reflexive if every element is related to itself, and antireflexive if none are. A relation can be neither, if some elements are related to themselves and some aren’t! (One relation is both, but that’s an exercise.)

In all of this section’s examples you should draw a digraph for each relation yourself and make sure you agree with which properties each relation has.

Examples. Let X={a,b,c,d}X = \{a,b,c,d\}X={a,b,c,d}. Consider the relations R1={(a,b),(a,d),(b,c),(b,d),(d,b),(d,c)}, R_1 = \{ (a,b), (a,d), (b,c), (b,d), (d,b), (d,c) \},R1​={(a,b),(a,d),(b,c),(b,d),(d,b),(d,c)}, R2={(a,a),(a,d),(b,b),(b,d),(c,c),(c,d),(d,d)}, R_2 = \{ (a,a), (a,d), (b,b), (b,d), (c,c), (c,d), (d,d) \},R2​={(a,a),(a,d),(b,b),(b,d),(c,c),(c,d),(d,d)}, R3={(a,b),(b,b),(b,c),(c,d),(d,a),(d,d)},R_3 = \{(a,b), (b,b), (b,c),(c,d),(d,a), (d,d)\},R3​={(a,b),(b,b),(b,c),(c,d),(d,a),(d,d)}, as well as the full relation X×XX \times XX×X and the empty relation ∅\varnothing∅.

The relations R2R_2R2​ and X×XX\times XX×X are reflexive as they contain all pairs of the form (x,x)(x,x)(x,x). The relations R1R_1R1​ and ∅\varnothing∅ are likewise antireflexive. The relation R3R_3R3​ is neither reflexive nor antireflexive, as it contains some of these “diagonal pairs” but not all.

Definition 15.2.3 A relation RRR on a set XXX is symmetric if for all x,y∈Xx, y \in Xx,y∈X where (x,y)∈R(x,y) \in R(x,y)∈R, then (y,x)∈R(y,x) \in R(y,x)∈R. Such a pair (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) is said to be invertible.

Definition 15.2.4 A relation RRR on a set XXX is antisymmetric if for all x,y∈Xx, y \in Xx,y∈X where (x,y)∈R(x,y) \in R(x,y)∈R, then (y,x)∉R(y,x) \not\in R(y,x)​∈R unless x=yx=yx=y. Equivalently the only invertible pairs in an antisymmetric relation are the diagonal pairs.

It is crucial to understand that symmetry and antisymmetry are two ends of a spectrum, measuring how many of the pairs in the relation are invertible. If they all are, the relation is symmetric. We would like to begin the next sentence with “if none are” but this is actually impossible, because if (x,x)∈R(x,x) \in R(x,x)∈R then it is automatically invertible. In other words the fewest amount of pairs that can be inverted are the diagonal pairs. So, an antisymmetric relation is one where the only invertible pairs are on the diagonal. Finally, a relation may be neither or both.

Examples. As before let X={a,b,c,d}X = \{a,b,c,d\}X={a,b,c,d} and consider the relations R1={(a,b),(a,d),(b,c),(b,d),(d,b),(d,c)}, R_1 = \{ (a,b), (a,d), (b,c), (b,d), (d,b), (d,c) \},R1​={(a,b),(a,d),(b,c),(b,d),(d,b),(d,c)}, R2={(a,a),(a,d),(b,b),(b,d),(c,c),(c,d),(d,d)}, R_2 = \{ (a,a), (a,d), (b,b), (b,d), (c,c), (c,d), (d,d) \},R2​={(a,a),(a,d),(b,b),(b,d),(c,c),(c,d),(d,d)}, R3={(a,b),(b,b),(b,c),(c,d),(d,a),(d,d)},R_3 = \{(a,b), (b,b), (b,c),(c,d),(d,a), (d,d)\},R3​={(a,b),(b,b),(b,c),(c,d),(d,a),(d,d)}, as well as the full relation X×XX \times XX×X and the empty relation ∅\varnothing∅.

The relation X×XX \times XX×X is symmetric, because it contains all the possible pairs; so every (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) will find its (y,x)(y,x)(y,x). It is less obvious but equally true that ∅\varnothing∅ is symmetric. The definition is that every pair must be invertible; if there are no pairs then the definition is satisfied automatically.

The relations R1R_1R1​, R2R_2R2​, and R3R_3R3​ are each not symmetric because they contain a pair that is not invertible. The relation R1R_1R1​ has (a,d)(a,d)(a,d) but no (d,a)(d,a)(d,a); R2R_2R2​ has (b,d)(b,d)(b,d) but no (d,b)(d,b)(d,b); and R3R_3R3​ has (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) but no (b,a)(b,a)(b,a), for example.

Of these, R1R_1R1​ is not antisymmetric, because it has “some” symmetry (the pairs (b,d)(b,d)(b,d) and (d,b)(d,b)(d,b)). The relations R2R_2R2​ and R3R_3R3​ are antisymmetric. The empty set ∅\varnothing∅ manages to be both symmetric and antisymmetric because just as there are no pairs to invert, there are also no pairs to not invert. Vacuousness!

The final property to discuss is transitivity. You have heard this word before, both without this book (transitivity of equality is used to solve equations in algebra) and within (inclusion, implication, and divisibility are all transitive).

Definition 15.2.5 A relation is transitive if for all x,y,z∈Xx, y, z \in Xx,y,z∈X, whenever (x,y)∈R(x,y) \in R(x,y)∈R and (y,z)∈R(y,z) \in R(y,z)∈R we also have (x,z)∈R(x,z)\in R(x,z)∈R.

There are two implications of this definition. The first is that any local symmetry within a transitive relation – that is, the presence of an invertible pair – must involve a loop. That is, suppose we have (x,y)∈R(x,y) \in R(x,y)∈R and (y,x)∈R(y,x) \in R(y,x)∈R in our relation. If we replace zzz with xxx in the above definition it forces us to include the loop (x,x)(x,x)(x,x) in our relation.

The next implication involves a new definition.

Definition 15.2.6 Consider a relation RRR on the set X={x1,x2,…,xn}X = \{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n\}X={x1​,x2​,…,xn​}. A walk of length nnn is a sequence (x1,x2,…,xn,xn+1)(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n, x_{n+1})(x1​,x2​,…,xn​,xn+1​) where (xi,xi+1)∈R(x_i, x_{i+1}) \in R(xi​,xi+1​)∈R for all 1≤i≤n1 \le i \le n1≤i≤n.

(The length of the walk is a measure of the number of arrows involved, not the number of elements in the sequence.)

The second implication is that in a transitive relation, if (xi)(x_i)(xi​) is a path beginning at x1x_1x1​ and ending at xnx_nxn​, then x1x_1x1​ must be related to xnx_nxn​.

Examples. One more time: Let X={a,b,c,d}X = \{a,b,c,d\}X={a,b,c,d} and consider the relations R1={(a,b),(a,d),(b,c),(b,d),(d,b),(d,c)}, R_1 = \{ (a,b), (a,d), (b,c), (b,d), (d,b), (d,c) \},R1​={(a,b),(a,d),(b,c),(b,d),(d,b),(d,c)}, R2={(a,a),(a,d),(b,b),(b,d),(c,c),(c,d),(d,d)}, R_2 = \{ (a,a), (a,d), (b,b), (b,d), (c,c), (c,d), (d,d) \},R2​={(a,a),(a,d),(b,b),(b,d),(c,c),(c,d),(d,d)}, R3={(a,b),(b,b),(b,c),(c,d),(d,a),(d,d)},R_3 = \{(a,b), (b,b), (b,c),(c,d),(d,a), (d,d)\},R3​={(a,b),(b,b),(b,c),(c,d),(d,a),(d,d)}, as well as the full relation X×XX \times XX×X and the empty relation ∅\varnothing∅.

The relation R1R_1R1​ is missing the edge (a,c)(a,c)(a,c), for example, the loop (b,b)(b,b)(b,b), so it is not transitive.

However, R2R_2R2​ is transitive. There are no pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) and (y,z)(y,z)(y,z) missing their (x,z)(x,z)(x,z). A common mistake is to ask, “Shouldn’t we require (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) for transitivity?” but neither aaa nor bbb are actually related to each other. Both are related to ddd, but the direction of the arrow matters. (If the (b,d)(b,d)(b,d) arrow were reversed, then a (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) arrow would be necessary.)

The relation R3R_3R3​ is not transitive. It is missing many edges required for transitivity; (b,d)(b,d)(b,d) is one example. As an exercise, try to find all of the missing edges that keep R1R_1R1​ and R3R_3R3​ from being transitive.

The relation X×XX\times XX×X is transitive because it contains all possible pairs. No pairs can possibly be missing, so it is transitive “by default.” Likewise ∅\varnothing∅ is transitive because there are no pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) and (y,z)(y,z)(y,z) that can fail to have their (x,z)(x,z)(x,z).

Takeaways

  • A relation takes the idea of a relationship and “makes it mathematical” so that it may be studied with the tools of mathematics.
  • A relation is a subset of the product of two sets. Relations may be represented as sets of pairs, Boolean matrices, or directed graphs.
  • A relation on a set XXX may be reflexive or antireflexive depending on how many of the elements of XXX are related to themselves.
  • A relation on XXX may be symmetric or antisymmetric depending on how many of its relationships “go the other way.”
  • A relation on XXX may be transitive depending on how information “flows” through the relation.

Chapter 15 problems

16. Closure and composition

Review.

  • Chapter 1: That throwaway comment about infinite unions.
  • Chapter 14: The Boolean matrix product and its application to logic.

Many times we will have a mathematical object in hand but desire it to have a property it does not have. For example, suppose I have the natural numbers N\mathbf{N}N, but would like to be able to subtract these numbers. Sometimes I will be successful. For instance, 5−3=2∈N5-3=2 \in \mathbf{N}5−3=2∈N. But othertimes I will not; say, in the case of 3−5=−23-5=-23−5=−2, which is not a natural number.

Then we construct a new object, the closure of the original, that contains the same data and the minimum amount of extra data required to allow the desired property. In the case of closing N\mathbf{N}N under subtraction, the result is Z\mathbf{Z}Z, the smallest set containing both the natural numbers and the results of subtracting any two natural numbers.

A closure YYY of the set XXX under the property PPP must satisfy the following three conditions:

  1. YYY must have property PPP.
  2. X⊆YX \subseteq YX⊆Y. In other words, YYY must be a superset of XXX. (“Subset” and “superset” are converses.)
  3. For any ZZZ such that ZZZ has property PPP and X⊆ZX \subseteq ZX⊆Z, it must also be the case that Y⊆ZY \subseteq ZY⊆Z. In this sense YYY is minimal among the supersets of XXX that have PPP. (Chapter 18 will make more sense of this idea, but not specifically as it pertains to closure.)

In this chapter we will close a relation under reflexiveness, symmetry, and transitivity. The third of these will require a detour into the operation of composing relations, and finally provide the response to Chapter 14’s call.

16.1 Reflexive and symmetric closures

In this section, RRR is a relation on the set XXX. The set XXX need not be finite unless we want to talk about a matrix or a directed graph.

Example. Suppose we have the relation R={(a,b),(a,c),(b,b),(c,b)}R = \{(a,b), (a,c), (b,b), (c,b)\}R={(a,b),(a,c),(b,b),(c,b)} on {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c}. To construct the reflexive closure of RRR, we must add the pairs (a,a)(a,a)(a,a) and (c,c)(c,c)(c,c). (Notice (b,b)∈R(b,b)\in R(b,b)∈R already.) So the reflexive closure of RRR is the new relation {(a,a),(a,b),(a,c),(b,b),(c,b)}. \{(a,a),(a,b),(a,c),(b,b),(c,b)\}.{(a,a),(a,b),(a,c),(b,b),(c,b)}.

Definition 16.1.1 Given a set XXX, the diagonal relation Δ\DeltaΔ on XXX is the relation Δ={(x,x)  ∣  x∈X}. \Delta = \{(x,x) \;|\; x \in X \}.Δ={(x,x)∣x∈X}.

The diagonal relation is the smallest reflexive relation on a set.

Definition 16.1.2 Given a relation RRR on a set XXX, the reflexive closure of RRR is the relation R∪ΔR \cup \DeltaR∪Δ.

In other words, to close a relation under reflexiveness it is only necessary to ensure it contains all the pairs in the diagonal relation.

Are these really definitions? Well, no. In the Form of discrete math textbook in the library of Heaven, the definition of closure is the one given in the preamble to the section – in this case, the smallest reflexive superset of RRR – and then it is a theorem that R∪ΔR \cup \DeltaR∪Δ is the reflexive closure. (It is also a theorem that a closure is necessarily unique, but this is easier to prove and only needs proving once for all closures.) Fortunately for us, this is not the Form of the discrete math textbook in the library of Heaven; so we will take these as definitions. Prove that they are truly what we say they are, as an exercise, if you like.

Next we will construct the symmetric closure of any relation.

Example. Again take R={(a,b),(a,c),(b,b),(c,b)}R = \{(a,b), (a,c), (b,b), (c,b)\}R={(a,b),(a,c),(b,b),(c,b)} on {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c}. To construct the symmetric closure of RRR, we must add the pairs (b,a)(b,a)(b,a), (c,a)(c,a)(c,a), and (b,c)(b,c)(b,c). (As previously discussed, (b,b)(b,b)(b,b) is invertible automatically.) Therefore the symmetric closure of RRR is {(a,b),(a,c),(b,a),(b,b),(b,c),(c,a),(c,b)}. \{(a,b), (a,c), (b,a), (b,b), (b,c), (c,a), (c,b)\}. {(a,b),(a,c),(b,a),(b,b),(b,c),(c,a),(c,b)}.

Definition 16.1.3 Given a relation RRR on a set XXX, its inverse relation is the relation R−1={(y,x)  ∣  (x,y)∈R}. R^{-1} = \{ (y,x) \; | \; (x,y) \in R \}.R−1={(y,x)∣(x,y)∈R}.

Example. You have seen this before. If fff is a function that has an inverse and (x,y)∈f(x,y) \in f(x,y)∈f (meaning y=f(x)y=f(x)y=f(x)), then (y,x)∈f−1(y,x) \in f^{-1}(y,x)∈f−1 (meaning x=f(y)x=f(y)x=f(y)).

Definition 16.1.4 Given a relation RRR on a set XXX, the symmetric closure of RRR is the relation R∪R−1R \cup R^{-1}R∪R−1.

16.2 Towards a transitive closure

We can’t define a transitive closure yet, but we can probably build one. Let’s do an example that is particularly relevant at the time this book was written.

Example. In the past two weeks, Alicia has hung out with Bob. Bob and Carlos are roommates, and Davina was Carlos’s cashier at the grocery store the other day. Davina lives with her boyfriend, Erik. If Alicia gets sick, who is at risk?

The underlying relation is
R={(a,b),(b,c),(c,d),(d,e)} R = \{ (a,b), (b,c), (c,d), (d,e) \} R={(a,b),(b,c),(c,d),(d,e)}
on the set {a,b,c,d,e}\{a,b,c,d,e\}{a,b,c,d,e} (where aaa refers to Alicia, etc.), the set of all pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) where xxx interacted with yyy over the past two weeks. However, this is not the relation that totally represents the spread of the illness, because if yyy was exposed to the illness in xxx and likewise zzz was exposed by xxx, then zzz could have caught something from yyy. So if (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) and (y,z)(y,z)(y,z) are in RRR, we would like (x,z)(x,z)(x,z) to be in our relation. Therefore we are looking for the transitive closure of RRR.

Transitivity is best understood visually. Draw a directed graph with vertices representing aaa, bbb, ccc, ddd, and eee, and draw arrows between aaa and bbb, bbb and ccc, ccc and ddd, and ddd and eee. These are the arrows in RRR. If our relation is to be transitive, these arrows will induce arrows between aaa and ccc, between bbb and ddd, and between ccc and eee, i.e. the arrows corresponding to the paths of length 2 in the original relation. Then we will get arrows between aaa and ddd and between bbb and eee (paths of length 3). Finally, we will draw one last arrow between aaa and eee (paths of length 4). You can verify for yourself that the relation R∗={(a,b),(a,c),(a,d),(a,e),(b,c),(b,d),(b,e),(c,d),(c,e),(d,e)} R^* = \{(a,b), (a,c), (a,d), (a,e), (b,c), (b,d), (b,e), (c,d), (c,e), (d,e)\}R∗={(a,b),(a,c),(a,d),(a,e),(b,c),(b,d),(b,e),(c,d),(c,e),(d,e)} is transitive.

If you understand that example, then you understand the idea of a transitive closure. It remains to put some formal machinery behind the idea.

16.3 Composition

Composition may be a familiar idea from algebra. Suppose you have functions fff and ggg such that f(x)=yf(x)=yf(x)=y and g(y)=zg(y)=zg(y)=z. Then you have a third function fgfgfg such that fg(x)=zfg(x) = zfg(x)=z, called the composition of fff and ggg.

You are extremely likely to have seen fgfgfg written as g∘fg\circ fg∘f before, and probably again outside of this book. We will have a material reason to prefer the fgfgfg notation very shortly. (And I prefer it for aesthetic reasons. - DW)

A composition of relations is the identical idea, but without the extra restrictions that make a relation into a function.

Definition 16.3.1 Let RRR be a relation from XXX to YYY, and SSS be a relation from YYY to ZZZ. Their composition is the relation RS={(x,z)  ∣  ∃y s.t. (x,y)∈R and (y,z)∈S}.RS = \{(x,z) \; | \; \exists y \text{ s.t. } (x,y) \in R \text { and } (y,z) \in S \}.RS={(x,z)∣∃y s.t. (x,y)∈R and (y,z)∈S}. The composition of RRR with itself nnn times is denoted RnR^nRn.

Again, elsewhere you may see RSRSRS written as S∘RS \circ RS∘R.

Example. Let R={(x1,y2),(x2,y3),(x3,y1)}R = \{ (x_1,y_2), (x_2,y_3), (x_3,y_1) \}R={(x1​,y2​),(x2​,y3​),(x3​,y1​)} be a relation from X={x1,x2,x3}X=\{x_1,x_2,x_3\}X={x1​,x2​,x3​} to Y={y1,y2,y3}Y=\{y_1,y_2,y_3\}Y={y1​,y2​,y3​}, and S={(y1,z1),(y1,z2),(y2,z2)}S = \{(y_1,z_1), (y_1,z_2), (y_2,z_2)\}S={(y1​,z1​),(y1​,z2​),(y2​,z2​)} be a relation from YYY to Z={z1,z2}Z=\{z_1,z_2\}Z={z1​,z2​}. What is RSRSRS?

The relation RSRSRS is the set of all pairs (x,z)(x,z)(x,z) for which there is a yyy “connecting” the xxx and the zzz. Looking at the given relations we may identify the following pairs: (x1,z2)(x_1,z_2)(x1​,z2​) via y2y_2y2​, (x3,z1)(x_3,z_1)(x3​,z1​) via y1y_1y1​, and (x3,z2)(x_3,z_2)(x3​,z2​) also via y1y_1y1​. Therefore RS={(x1,z2),(x3,z1),(x3,z2)}.RS = \{(x_1, z_2), (x_3,z_1), (x_3,z_2)\}.RS={(x1​,z2​),(x3​,z1​),(x3​,z2​)}.

The following diagram illustrates this composition.



Figure. A picture of the composition of two relations is shown. Two elements are related in the composition if a third in the middle set "bridges" them.

Observe that SRSRSR does not exist because the codomain of SSS is not the domain of RRR.

You may tell yourself, “I don’t want to draw this diagram every time I compute a composition.” And you may tell yourself, “If the relations involved were large, I would like to be able to make a computer do this job for me.” Fortunately this apparatus is already in place! Recall the criteria for a pair (xi,zj)(x_i,z_j)(xi​,zj​) appearing in the composition for sets whose elements are labeled numerically:

"xix_ixi​ is related to zjz_jzj​ if there exists a kkk such that xkx_kxk​ is related to yky_kyk​ and yky_kyk​ is related to zkz_kzk​."

You may recall this exact language has appeared before:

“The Boolean dot product of a row matrix (Ai)(A_i)(Ai​) and a column matrix (Cj)(C_j)(Cj​)" is 111 if there exists a kkk such that AkA_kAk​ and CkC_kCk​ are both 111.”

It is precisely the multiplication of Boolean matrices that will find the necessary yky_kyk​'s for us. Indeed,

Theorem 16.3.2 Let RRR and SSS be relations such that the composition RSRSRS exists. Then MRS=MR⊙MS, M_{RS} = M_R \odot M_S,MRS​=MR​⊙MS​, i.e. the matrix for RSRSRS is the product of the matrix for RRR with the matrix for SSS.

Example. In the last example we let R={(x1,y2),(x2,y3),(x3,y1)}R = \{ (x_1,y_2), (x_2,y_3), (x_3,y_1) \}R={(x1​,y2​),(x2​,y3​),(x3​,y1​)} be a relation from X={x1,x2,x3}X=\{x_1,x_2,x_3\}X={x1​,x2​,x3​} to Y={y1,y2,y3}Y=\{y_1,y_2,y_3\}Y={y1​,y2​,y3​}, and S={(y1,z1),(y1,z2),(y2,z2)}S = \{(y_1,z_1), (y_1,z_2), (y_2,z_2)\}S={(y1​,z1​),(y1​,z2​),(y2​,z2​)} be a relation from YYY to Z={z1,z2}Z=\{z_1,z_2\}Z={z1​,z2​}.

The matrix for RRR is MR=(010001100) M_R = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \right) MR​=⎝⎛​001​100​010​⎠⎞​ and the matrix for SSS is MS=(110100). M_S = \left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array} \right).MS​=⎝⎛​100​110​⎠⎞​. Their product is (010001100)(110100)=(010011), \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \right) \left( \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{array} \right), ⎝⎛​001​100​010​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​100​110​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​001​101​⎠⎞​, which is also the matrix for RSRSRS.

16.4 Transitive closure

Composition takes the pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) and (y,z)(y,z)(y,z) and returns (x,z)(x,z)(x,z), so you can already imagine how this would relate to transitivity. A transitive relation is one that contains all of its self-compositions.

Theorem 16.4.1 A relation RRR on a set XXX is transitive if and only if Rn⊆RR^n \subseteq RRn⊆R for all positive integers nnn.

Therefore, the smallest transitive relation containing RRR is the union of all of the RnR^nRn. You will recall a very, very long time ago that we defined the infinite union ⋃n=1∞Xn=X1∪X2∪⋯ \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty X_n = X_1 \cup X_2 \cup \cdots n=1⋃∞​Xn​=X1​∪X2​∪⋯ to be the set of all elements that are in at least one of the XiX_iXi​, and said that this definition would be needed exactly once in the book. Well, here we are!

Definition 16.4.2 The transitive closure of a relation RRR on a set XXX is the relation R∗=⋃n=1∞Rn. R^* = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty R^n.R∗=n=1⋃∞​Rn.

Of course, in practice, we will not need to calculate infinitely many composites. You will be able to tell that there are no new pairs that would arise from a new composition.

The following comment makes it easy to conceptualize RnR^nRn. Recall a walk of length nnn is a sequence (x1,x2,…,xn+1)(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_{n+1})(x1​,x2​,…,xn+1​) where (xi,xi+1)∈R(x_i,x_{i+1}) \in R(xi​,xi+1​)∈R. We can call these nnn-walks for short.

Theorem 16.4.3 Given a relation RRR on a set XXX, the relation RnR^nRn is precisely the set of all pairs (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) such that there is an nnn-walk in RRR beginning at xxx and ending at yyy.

Example. Consider the set X={w,x,y,z}X=\{w,x,y,z\}X={w,x,y,z} and the relation R={(w,x),(x,y),(y,z),(z,y)}R = \{(w,x), (x,y), (y,z), (z,y) \}R={(w,x),(x,y),(y,z),(z,y)}. Construct R∗R^*R∗.

We will find R2R^2R2 and R3R^3R3, and the union of these with RRR will be the transitive closure. (We will verify that R4R^4R4 will yield nothing new.)

To find R2R^2R2, find all of the pairs that are “two steps away” in the original relation. You may immediately name (w,y)(w,y)(w,y) and (x,z)(x,z)(x,z) as two such pairs, but there are two less obvious pairs: (y,y)(y,y)(y,y) and (z,z)(z,z)(z,z). Recall from the last chapter that any time you have invertible pairs in a transitive relation, that symmetry must produce loops; because yyy is related to zzz and zzz is related to yyy, for the relation to be transitive yyy must be related to yyy. (Same for zzz.) Therefore R2={(w,y),(x,z),(y,y),(z,z)}.R^2 = \{(w,y), (x,z), (y,y), (z,z)\}.R2={(w,y),(x,z),(y,y),(z,z)}.

The triple composite R3R^3R3 consists of all the pairs that are “three steps away,” which at first glance is just (w,z)(w,z)(w,z). In fact, if we stopped here we would be correct about R∗R^*R∗, but we should be careful: because of the loops in R2R^2R2 there are more pairs in R3R^3R3. For example, one iteration of RRR may take xxx to yyy; another takes yyy to zzz; and a third takes zzz back to yyy. Therefore the pair (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) is in R∗R^*R∗, even though it is also in RRR. Check for yourself that R3={(w,z),(x,y),(y,z),(z,y)} R^3 = \{(w,z), (x,y), (y,z), (z,y) \}R3={(w,z),(x,y),(y,z),(z,y)} is the set of all pairs that start and end 3-paths in the original relation.

Finally, we take the union of these three sets to make R∗={(w,x),(w,y),(w,z),(x,y),(x,z),(y,y),(y,z),(z,y),(z,z)}.R^*= \{(w,x), (w,y), (w,z), (x,y), (x,z), (y,y), (y,z), (z,y), (z,z)\}.R∗={(w,x),(w,y),(w,z),(x,y),(x,z),(y,y),(y,z),(z,y),(z,z)}.

Takeaways

  • In many fields of mathematics we would like to take one object and endow it with structure it does not necessarily already have, its closure with respect to that structure. We are not violating the golden rule, “Thou shalt not change anything in math”; rather we are creating an entirely new object that contains the data of the old object.
  • The reflexive closure of a relation is constructed by taking the union with the diagonal relation.
  • The symmetric closure of a relation is constructed by taking the union with its inverse.
  • Composition is a way of combining two relations, or a relation with itself.
  • The transitive closure of a relation is constructed by taking the infinite union of a relation and all compositions with itself.

Chapter 16 problems

17. Equivalence relations

Review:

  • Basic arithmetic! Numbers are back.
  • Chapter 4: Divisibility

17.1 Introduction

Consider the digraph generated by the relation RRR on X={a,b,c,d,e,f,g}X=\{a,b,c,d,e,f,g\}X={a,b,c,d,e,f,g}, where R={(a,a),(a,d),(a,g),R= \{ (a,a), (a,d), (a,g),R={(a,a),(a,d),(a,g), (b,b),(b,c),(b,e),(b,b), (b,c), (b,e),(b,b),(b,c),(b,e), (b,f),(c,b),(c,c),(b,f), (c,b), (c,c),(b,f),(c,b),(c,c), (c,e),(c,f),(d,a),(c,e), (c,f), (d,a),(c,e),(c,f),(d,a), (d,d),(d,g),(e,b),(d,d), (d,g), (e,b),(d,d),(d,g),(e,b), (e,c),(e,e),(e,f),(e,c), (e,e), (e,f),(e,c),(e,e),(e,f), (f,b),(f,c),(f,e),(f,f)}(f,b), (f,c), (f,e), (f,f)\}(f,b),(f,c),(f,e),(f,f)}. The digraph is drawn below:



Figure. The directed graph of the relation. Three elements occupy their own triangle, while the other four have their own square.

The most visually striking feature of this directed graph is that the set XXX is partitioned into separated pieces: the piece with aaa, ddd, and ggg; and the piece with bbb, ccc, eee, and fff.

To understand this phenomenon, what properties does RRR have? It is reflexive, it is symmetric, and it is transitive. (Verify these for yourself.) Taken together they imply a “fullness” of the relation; the arrow (a,d)(a,d)(a,d) brings with it the arrows (a,a)(a,a)(a,a), (d,a)(d,a)(d,a), and (d,d)(d,d)(d,d); if we add (d,g)(d,g)(d,g), we get (a,g)(a,g)(a,g), (g,d)(g,d)(g,d), (g,a)(g,a)(g,a), and (g,g)(g,g)(g,g).

Such a relation gets its own title.

Definition 17.1.1 An equivalence relation is any relation that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

Examples. The relation given by the statement x=yx=yx=y on any set XXX is an equivalence relation. In fact it is the prototypical equivalence relation, in the sense that the point of an equivalence relations is to get the idea of equality in a less strict way.

For example, the typical way to define equivalence on a set is to say that two sets XXX and YYY are isomorphic if ∣X∣=∣Y∣|X|=|Y|∣X∣=∣Y∣. This relation is an equivalence relation, but XXX and YYY do not need to actually be equal to be equivalent. This is the reason we freely rename the elements of a set whenever we like.

Another example is the equivalence of statements from Chapter 2, where ϕ≡ψ\phi \equiv \psiϕ≡ψ if ϕ↔ψ\phi \leftrightarrow \psiϕ↔ψ is a tautology.

Definition 17.1.2 Let RRR be an equivalence relation on a set XXX. The equivalence class of x∈Xx \in Xx∈X is the set of all elements to which it is equivalent: [x]={y∈X  ∣  (x,y)∈R}. [x] = \{ y \in X \; | \; (x,y) \in R \}.[x]={y∈X∣(x,y)∈R}.

Example. Let again R={(a,a),(a,d),(a,g),R= \{ (a,a), (a,d), (a,g),R={(a,a),(a,d),(a,g), (b,b),(b,c),(b,e),(b,b), (b,c), (b,e),(b,b),(b,c),(b,e), (b,f),(c,b),(c,c),(b,f), (c,b), (c,c),(b,f),(c,b),(c,c), (c,e),(c,f),(d,a),(c,e), (c,f), (d,a),(c,e),(c,f),(d,a), (d,d),(d,g),(e,b),(d,d), (d,g), (e,b),(d,d),(d,g),(e,b), (e,c),(e,e),(e,f),(e,c), (e,e), (e,f),(e,c),(e,e),(e,f), (f,b),(f,c),(f,e),(f,f)}(f,b), (f,c), (f,e), (f,f)\}(f,b),(f,c),(f,e),(f,f)} be a relation on X={a,b,c,d,e,f,g}X = \{a,b,c,d,e,f,g\}X={a,b,c,d,e,f,g} whose directed graph is drawn above. This relation divides its underlying set into the equivalence classes [a]={a,d,g} [a] = \{a,d,g\}[a]={a,d,g} and [b]={b,c,e,f},[b]=\{b,c,e,f\},[b]={b,c,e,f}, precisely the discrete “sections” of the digraph. Note that the name of the equivalence class is an arbitrarily chosen representative; [b][b][b], [c][c][c], [e][e][e], and [f][f][f] all refer to the same set.

17.2 Modular arithmetic

Now we consider a special equivalence relation on the set of integers.

Definition 17.2.1 Fix a nonzero integer aaa. We declare mmm and nnn to be congruent modulo a\boldsymbol{a}a, and write m≡n (mod a)m \equiv n \,(\text{mod }a)m≡n(mod a), if a∣(m−n)a|(m-n)a∣(m−n).

We are functionally declaring mmm and nnn “the same” if they differ by a multiple of aaa. In a way, we are “destroying” the information of aaa. Throughout even very different areas of mathematics, the word “modulo” or “mod” refers to collapsing some information in a structure, to be very vague.

Theorem 17.2.2 For a fixed nonzero integer aaa, congruence mod aaa defines an equivalence relation on Z\mathbf{Z}Z.

Proof. Up to you, in the exercises.

Examples. In the right context this relation is a familiar one. Suppose it is 10:00 in the morning. What time will it be 37 hours from now? Of course we subtract a full day, or 24 hours, from 37; so what time is it 13 hours from now? It will be 23:00 or 11:00 in the evening, depending on how you tell time. This addition is done modulo 24 (or 12).

A lot of trigonometry is done modulo 2π2\pi2π, but since 2π2\pi2π is not an integer, we don’t care about it in this book.

17≡33 (mod 8)17 \equiv 33 \,(\text{mod }8)17≡33(mod 8), because 33−17=1633-17=1633−17=16 and 8∣168|168∣16. You may also think of this as being true because the remainder of both 171717 and 333333 is 111 upon being divided by 888.

However, 23≢49 (mod 5)23 \not\equiv 49 \,(\text{mod }5)23​≡49(mod 5) because 49−23=2649-23=2649−23=26, which is not divisible by 555.

The equivalence class of a given element mod aaa is not difficult to generate with the following observation, via example. Suppose we want to know the equivalene class of 111111 modulo 666. We are looking for integers mmm satisfying 6∣(11−m)6|(11-m)6∣(11−m); equivalently, integers mmm for which there exists a kkk such that 11−m=6k11-m=6k11−m=6k. Or, m=11−6km=11-6km=11−6k. Therefore, we will allow kkk to run through all of its options–both positive and negative–so the integers in the equivalence class of 111111 mod 666 are just the integers that are 111111 plus some multiple of 666: [11]={…,−7,−1,5,11,17,23,…}. [11] = \{\ldots, -7, -1, 5, 11, 17, 23, \ldots \}.[11]={…,−7,−1,5,11,17,23,…}. Another equivalence class mod 6 is [3]={…,−9,−3,3,9,15,…}. [3] = \{\ldots, -9, -3, 3, 9, 15, \ldots \}.[3]={…,−9,−3,3,9,15,…}. Observe that there is one equivalence class per possible remainder when dividing by 666. The smallest non-negative member of each class is the remainder of all the members of its class modulo 6.

Finally, we will note some useful algebraic properties of this relation.

Theorem 17.2.3 Suppose u≡vu \equiv vu≡v and x≡yx \equiv yx≡y modulo aaa. Then (u+x)≡(v+y) (mod a) (u+x) \equiv (v+y) \,(\text{mod }a) (u+x)≡(v+y)(mod a) and ux≡vy (mod a). ux \equiv vy \,(\text{mod }a).ux≡vy(mod a).

Example. In certain cryptography contexts it is helpful to know the remainders of large integers mod something, but it may expensive to calculate those large integers. Instead we exploit the above theorem. Suppose we want to know the value of (1912−27×48) (mod 9).(19^{12} - 27 \times 48) \,(\text{mod }9).(1912−27×48)(mod 9).

First, observe that since 272727 is divisible by 999, 27≡027 \equiv 027≡0. (It is okay to drop the “mod9mod 9mod9” here because it should be clear from context after the above paragraph.) Since 000 times anything is 000, (1912−27×48)≡1912(19^{12} - 27 \times 48) \equiv 19^{12}(1912−27×48)≡1912.

Next, observe 19≡119 \equiv 119≡1. Then, 1912≡11219^{12} \equiv 1^{12}1912≡112, which is just 111.

So, (1912−27×48)≡1 (mod 9)(19^{12} - 27 \times 48) \equiv 1 \,(\text{mod }9)(1912−27×48)≡1(mod 9). In fact, since 111 is the smallest nonnegative member of its equivalence class, it is the remainder we would get if we divided whatever 1912−27×4819^{12}-27\times 481912−27×48 is by 999.

Takeaways

  • An equivalence relation is any reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relation.
  • Equivalence relations are meant to capture the idea of two things being functionally the same (from a certain point of view) without necessarily being equal. Examples abound even in this course.
  • An important equivalence relation on the set of integers is the relation of congruence modulo aaa, which respects addition and multiplication as well.

Chapter 17 problems

18. Partial orders

Review.

  • Chapter 1: Subsets, again.
  • Chapter 4: Divisibility.
  • Chapter 14: Boolean algebras.

In the last chapter we looked at equivalence relations, which generalize the idea of equality. Partial orders will do the same for inequalities. How can we say one object is “less than” another when the two objects are not numbers? You may be able to think of a way to order sets, or strings, or matrices. That way is probably a partial order.

18.1 Introduction

The secret ingredient to order is that an order must only go one way. If xxx is less than yyy, the only way that yyy should be able to be less than xxx is if the two are equal (and by “less than” we really mean “less than or equal to”). Fortunately, we have a word for this: antisymmetry!

Definition 18.1.1 A relation is a partial order if it is reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive. If RRR is a partial order on a set XXX and (x,y)∈R(x,y) \in R(x,y)∈R, we write x≤Ryx \le_R yx≤R​y, x⪯yx \preceq yx⪯y, or x≤yx \le yx≤y. The third is only used when the partial order is clear from context.

Examples. The prototypical partial order is the relation x≤yx \le yx≤y on the integers. This relation is reflexive (any integer is less than or equal to itself), antisymmetric (x≤yx \le yx≤y and y≤xy \le xy≤x means x=yx=yx=y), and transitive (as we saw in Chapter 8).

Given a family of sets, there are two “natural” ways to order them: by inclusion, or by size. The first is the relation where sets EEE and FFF are related if and only if E⊆FE \subseteq FE⊆F. The other is given by ∣E∣≤∣F∣|E| \le |F|∣E∣≤∣F∣. In Chapter 15 you verified that the former was a partial order; you will verify the latter in this chapter.

Given a set of integers we may say that mmm is related to nnn if and only if m∣nm|nm∣n. In Chapter 4 you proved that this is a partial order (even if you didn’t know it at the time).

Why the word “partial”? Take the last example, the order defined by divisibility, and suppose our underlying set is all of Z\mathbf{Z}Z. Neither 3∣53|53∣5 nor 5∣35|35∣3. Since we have two elements that cannot be ordered, the order is only partial. The following definitions formalize the notion.

Definition 18.1.2 Suppose that RRR is a partial order on a set XXX. If x⪯yx \preceq yx⪯y or y⪯xy \preceq xy⪯x in the partial order, we say xxx and yyy are comparable; if not, they are incomparable.

Definition 18.1.3 An order on a set XXX is total or linear if xxx and yyy are comparable for every x,y∈Xx,y \in Xx,y∈X.

Example. The usual order on the integers is a total order. The divisibility order is total if restricted to the right set, for example, the set of powers of 222.

Definition 18.1.4 A set XXX is well-ordered if it has a total order ⪯\preceq⪯ and an element x0x_0x0​ such that x0⪯xx_0 \preceq xx0​⪯x for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X.

In language we will learn later, a well-ordered set is a set with a total order and a “minimum” element.

Example. The poster child for well-ordered sets is N\mathbf{N}N, with the usual total order and the least element 000. Observe that one of the most important features of N\mathbf{N}N, the validity of mathematical induction, is not special to N\mathbf{N}N at all: all we need is somewhere to start and a way to move “forward” through the set. So, well-ordered sets are precisely those for which mathematical induction is possible.

18.2 Hasse diagrams

As relations, partial orders can be represented with directed graphs. Let’s give it a try with a simple partial order: the inclusion order on the power set of {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c}.



Figure. The directed graph for the power set of a three-element set, ordered under inclusion. The number of arrows make it incomprehensible.

This visual is, in a word, awful. There are too many arrows! However, the fact that we are dealing with a partial order implies that certain arrows are redundant. Since every partial order is reflexive, we can lose the loops. Transitivity says that the edges from ∅\varnothing∅ to {a}\{a\}{a} and from {a}\{a\}{a} to {a,b}\{a,b\}{a,b} are sufficient; we do not need the edge from ∅\varnothing∅ to {a,b}\{a,b\}{a,b} (and etc.) Finally if we impose the restriction that all edges flow upward, we can draw the following, much more pleasant, picture.



Figure. The Hasse diagram of the previous digraph, where the redundant arrows (those implied by reflexiveness and transitivity) are removed.

Such a diagram is called a Hasse diagram.

Definition 18.2.1 Suppose XXX is partially ordered and x,y,z∈Xx,y,z \in Xx,y,z∈X. If x≤yx \le yx≤y and there is no intermediate element zzz such that x≤zx \le zx≤z and y≤zy \le zy≤z, we say yyy covers xxx.

Definition 18.2.2 The Hasse diagram of a partial order is a graph on a set XXX where there is an edge from a vertex xxx up to yyy if and only if yyy covers xxx in the order.

Example. Let X={a,b,c,d,e}X=\{a,b,c,d,e\}X={a,b,c,d,e} and R={(a,a),(a,b),(a,e),R=\{(a,a),(a,b),(a,e),R={(a,a),(a,b),(a,e), (b,b),(b,e),(c,b),(b,b),(b,e),(c,b),(b,b),(b,e),(c,b), (c,c),(c,e),(d,b),(c,c),(c,e),(d,b),(c,c),(c,e),(d,b), (d,c),(d,d),(d,e),(e,e)}(d,c),(d,d),(d,e),(e,e)\}(d,c),(d,d),(d,e),(e,e)}. Draw the Hasse diagram for this partial order.

To draw a Hasse diagram out of a set of pairs, observe that the elements related to the most other elements should be on the bottom of the diagram, while the elements related to the fewest other elements should be near the top. You can typically then “fit in” the others. Here is the diagram for the above relation:



Figure. The Hasse diagram for the example order.

18.3 Extreme features of a partial order

We will close by discussing various “extreme” features a partial order can have.

Definition 18.3.1 Let XXX be a partially ordered set. We say that xxx is less than yyy (in the partial order) if x⪯yx \preceq yx⪯y, and then yyy is greater than xxx.

This definition might seem weird, but remember that we are not necessarily talking about numbers. Once everyone knows which partial order is being discussed, we use “less than” and “greater than” to describe relations within the order.

Definition 18.3.2 An element xxx in a partially ordered set XXX is minimal/maximal if it is not greater/less than any other element. If the minimal/maximal element is unique, it is called the minimum/maximum.

Example. It is important to note that minimal does not mean less than everything; it means not greater than anything, and these are not the same! Consider the order {(w,w),(w,y),(x,x),\{(w,w), (w,y), (x,x),{(w,w),(w,y),(x,x), (x,y),(x,z),(y,y),(z,z)}(x,y), (x,z), (y,y), (z,z)\}(x,y),(x,z),(y,y),(z,z)}. Its Hasse diagram is shown below:



Figure. The Hasse diagram for the example order, with two minimal elements and two maximal elements.

Above, www is minimal, but it is not less than zzz. (Likewise zzz is maximal even though it is not greater than www.)

Definition 18.3.3 Fix a subset AAA of the partially ordered set XXX. A lower bound/upper bound of AAA is any element of XXX that is less/greater than every element in AAA.

Example. Consider the order {(a,a),(a,b),(a,c),\{(a,a), (a,b), (a,c),{(a,a),(a,b),(a,c), (a,d),(a,e),(a,f),(b,b),(a,d), (a,e), (a,f), (b,b),(a,d),(a,e),(a,f),(b,b), (b,c),(b,d),(b,e),(b,f),(b,c), (b,d), (b,e), (b,f),(b,c),(b,d),(b,e),(b,f), (c,c),(c,e),(c,f),(d,d),(c,c), (c,e), (c,f), (d,d),(c,c),(c,e),(c,f),(d,d), (d,e),(d,f),(e,e),(f,f),(d,e), (d,f), (e,e), (f,f),(d,e),(d,f),(e,e),(f,f), (g,d),(g,e),(g,f),(g,g)}(g,d), (g,e), (g,f), (g,g)\}(g,d),(g,e),(g,f),(g,g)} and the subset A={b,c,d}A=\{b,c,d\}A={b,c,d} of the ordered set.



Figure. A Hasse diagram with a three-element subset highlighted.

The upper bounds of AAA are the elements eee and fff, because both are greater than every element in AAA.

The lower bounds of AAA are aaa and bbb. Since partial orders are reflexive, bbb is “less than” (remember, really “less than or equal to”) itself. Because ggg is only less than ddd, it is not a lower bound of AAA.

Definition 18.3.4 Let AAA be a subset of a partially ordered set. The greatest lower bound of AAA, if it exists, is the maximum element of the set of lower bounds of AAA. The greatest lower bound is denoted glb\text{glb}glb and sometimes called the infemum, or inf\text{inf}inf, of the set. (The least upper bound, lub\text{lub}lub, supremum, or sup\text{sup}sup is the minimum upper bound.)

Sound familiar? Indeed, we have talked about finding “tightest bounds” when we discussed growth rates of sequences all the way back in Chapter 7.

Example. As before take the order {(a,a),(a,b),(a,c),\{(a,a), (a,b), (a,c),{(a,a),(a,b),(a,c), (a,d),(a,e),(a,f),(b,b),(a,d), (a,e), (a,f), (b,b),(a,d),(a,e),(a,f),(b,b), (b,c),(b,e),(b,f),(b,c), (b,e), (b,f),(b,c),(b,e),(b,f), (c,c),(c,e),(c,f),(d,d),(c,c), (c,e), (c,f), (d,d),(c,c),(c,e),(c,f),(d,d), (d,e),(d,f),(e,e),(f,f),(d,e), (d,f), (e,e), (f,f),(d,e),(d,f),(e,e),(f,f), (g,d),(g,e),(g,f),(g,g)}(g,d), (g,e), (g,f), (g,g)\}(g,d),(g,e),(g,f),(g,g)} whose Hasse diagram is shown above. And again fix the set A={b,c,d}A=\{b,c,d\}A={b,c,d}. The greatest lower bound is the element bbb; so, glb(A)=b\text{glb}(A)=bglb(A)=b.

The least upper bound of AAA does not exist. The set of upper bounds of AAA is {e,f}\{e,f\}{e,f}, neither of which is less than the other.

You may have noticed that some Hasse diagrams tend to “sprawl,” while others have pleasing geometric shapes. Our final definition puts some structure on that idea.

Definition 18.3.5 A partially ordered set is a lattice if any pair of elements has both a least upper bound and a greatest lower bound.

Examples. The set {a,b,c,d,e,f,g}\{a,b,c,d,e,f,g\}{a,b,c,d,e,f,g} with the order {(a,a),(a,b),(a,c),\{(a,a), (a,b), (a,c),{(a,a),(a,b),(a,c), (a,d),(a,e),(a,f),(b,b),(a,d), (a,e), (a,f), (b,b),(a,d),(a,e),(a,f),(b,b), (b,c),(b,e),(b,f),(b,c), (b,e), (b,f),(b,c),(b,e),(b,f), (c,c),(c,e),(c,f),(d,d),(c,c), (c,e), (c,f), (d,d),(c,c),(c,e),(c,f),(d,d), (d,e),(d,f),(e,e),(f,f),(d,e), (d,f), (e,e), (f,f),(d,e),(d,f),(e,e),(f,f), (g,d),(g,e),(g,f),(g,g)}(g,d), (g,e), (g,f), (g,g)\}(g,d),(g,e),(g,f),(g,g)} from the last two examples is not a lattice, because (for instance) the pair {e,f}\{e,f\}{e,f} fails to have a least upper bound.

An example of a lattice is the inclusion order on any power set; see Section 18.2 for an example. Surprisingly (or maybe not), any linear order is a lattice, even though they don’t visually “look like” lattices. Take a pair {a,b}\{a,b\}{a,b} in a linear order where (say) a⪯ba \preceq ba⪯b (it’s either that or the other way around). Then, the greatest lower bound of the pair is aaa and the least upper bound of the pair is bbb.

Any Boolean algebra yields a lattice, and any finite lattice yields a Boolean algebra. This is an exercise.

Takeaways

  • A partial order generalizes the idea of inequality to objects that aren’t numbers.
  • Examples include inclusion of sets and divisibility of integers.
  • A partial order can be visually represented by a Hasse diagram.
  • There are several ways to discuss extreme elements in a partial order: minimal/maximal elements, minimum/maximum elements, and lower/upper bounds.

Chapter 18 problems

ONE MORE FINAL: Oh, the places you’ll go

Congratulations! You have either read all of, or scrolled to the end of, Elementary discrete mathematics. What next?

If you are a computer science student in your first year, i.e. a member of the target audience of this book, you either will take calculus or have taken it recently. Asymptotics can be phrased in terms of limits. The binomial theorem will give you a powerful tool in computing difficult integrals. You will look at infinite sequences and sums. Most importantly, you have hopefully gained some confidence in mathematics, and you will go on with a greater ability to read and do math.

With perseverance and a good group of people to work with, there’s not a lot you can’t do after reading this book. I don’t claim this book is magic, or has taught you everything you need to know. What I do claim is that once you know about sets and how to read and write a proof, and maybe have some familiarity with recursion, the tapestry of mathematics is open to you, especially after learning the language of calculus and the examples therein. I am particularly fond of combinatorics and category theory.

Don’t want to do anymore math? That’s fine too, I guess. Maybe this book helped you organize your mental machinery for other areas of your life. Maybe you have found within you a confidence to solve problems you did not think you could.

Whatever powers, if any, this book gave you, use them for good, and live well.
